reviewText:
If you've played World of Warships (or World of Tanks, for that matter), the game progression is similar -- play ships in PvP matches against other players to earn EXP to unlock better modules and/or ships.

Where this title departs from being just a mere World of Warships clone is as follows:

+ Has submarines, which are powerful if let loose among the capital ships in the back of the fleet, but are weak against destroyers.
+ Torpedoes are manually fired one-at-a-time, requiring manual input to nicely spread, but also allowing for fine-tuning of said spreads.
+ Ammunition isn't unlimited! You can't just fire all the time and expect to have ammunition (especially torpedoes) left by the end of a match.
+ Battleships are actually powerful with their main guns, and can lob rounds well out of their own view range (which is what scouts like destroyers are useful for!).
+ Aircraft carriers can pick and choose their own plane loadout, allowing for customization to your own playstyle.

- Because of battleships being really powerful, they're currently (as of this writing) somewhat over-used. Matches can often have more battleships than other ship types.
- Cruisers as a whole tend to be VERY sparsely populated (because of the glut of battleships, which easily shred cruisers).
- Physics is arcadey at times. Ships can accelerate or stop much faster than would be possible for a ship of their size (battleships getting up to speed within a few seconds, for example).

Gameplay is somewhat of a mix between Battlestations: Pacific and World of Warships.

Overall I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a good naval-themed game.

reviewText:
Instead of playing like a WoWS clone, it plays out more like a battlestations clone.

-The ability to gain control of your secondary and AA armament is highly appreciated, instead of waiting for RNG to do it's work and shoot down incoming bombers, manual AA armament control puts the power back in the hands of the player.

-Carrier gameplay is much much more interesting. I have both T9 CVs in WoWS and over the time from the CBT till now, WG's balance changes to CVs have shown their lack of vision for how they want CVs to play out. Instead of fixed loadouts, Steel Ocean goes close to the NavyField style of allowing you to customize your squadrons in combat to fit the dynamics of the situation. Additionally, the existence of dedicated scouting aircraft really pushes the versatility of carriers even further - beyond mere torpedo dispensers. Additionally, a division allows up to 2 carriers, which means that if you a friend both love carriers and want to play them, none of you will have to compromise and play a less desirable class of ship unlike in the case of WoWS.

-Aiming while moving is a lot more inaccurate in Steel Ocean, somewhat a approximation of real life. While encouraging people to stop to aim in a fast-paced arcady game is indeed a dubious design decision, it can't be dismissed that aiming requires more skill than WoWS and at the back of the minds of ship captains remains the cost vs risk analysis of stopping for better aim but becoming a better target.

-No torpedo lead indicator. Once again, another aspect from battlestations - the lack of torpedo lead indicator means that torpedoes are more for area denial and close range torpedo attacks are needed to ensure a successful torpedo attack. Additionally, the torpedo arming distance is feels much further than WoWS, which prevents DD suicide charges.

-Submarines. Submarine gameplay is sufficiently balanced and fun in steel ocean. There is a huge step away from historical realism, but considering how WoWS threw historical realism out of the window since 0.3.7 in the CBT, the argument that submarines in WoWS will not be historically realistic" does not hold water. reviewText:
After im close to Tier VII and played every Class to at Least Tier 5 i would like to share my Experiences so far with the Community.

First of, this game has, at least in my Eyes, no real Parallels to WoWS. If anything it would be more like Navy Field. It's more Arcade then WoWS (played about 1550 Matches in it, got a Tier X CV and BB). And for me, it does various things better.  I would say it rewards your personal Skills much more then wows because the game doesn't take you by the Hand. Let me elaborate:

- Torps are fired one by one and manually. This gives you much more Freedom about timing and placing, but can also be harder because you don't have an aim assist like in wows
- The BBs and CAs got an Artillery View for their Main Batteries which is pretty much like in WoT or AW, So you will have to Focus for a few secs instead of hit and run
- The whole Spotting mechanic is a lot different and rewards XP / Points for the Spotters. It also makes the Game much more Rock / Paper / Scissors.
- CVs are pretty well implemented right now. They did several things i critizied in WoWS over Months. A maximum Number of Planes that can be started at a time, a max of 3 squads a time, limited fuel and far less Spotting range. But also, you can chose manually what kind of Layout you want ( you can configurate the number of plane types you want aboard  in the Maintenance Screen)  Also, onward to my next point, your Planes will die more often because..
- You will have to aim your AA manually, and i love that Fact. If your Aim is good it allows you to annihalate Torp Sqads even before they can drop. Pretty much what i said at the start, it rewards personal Skill.

The only real Downside right now is that there are still not enough players, but hopefully my Review might change that :P If you liked Navy Field or WoWS you should at least give it a Try. It wont be your Harm. Right now, after 500+ games in it, i can't really see any Reason to go back to WoWS.

reviewText:
This is a suprisingly fun mix of Navy Fields, World of Warships and World of Tanks. Taking influences from all of them and turning them into an interesting and entertaining F2P title.

After playing a few hours I personally start to prefer it over WoWS; it features a more demanding gunnery with maneuvering and aim-time having more influence on spread of a volley than in WoWs, also you get manual control over your secondaries and heavy AAA which I personaly prefer. While the ranges are 'shorter' when you go by the range displayed, they feel a lot longer than in WoWs right from the start thanks to the different scale of the ships themselves and the battlefield.
Also, Torpedos in this game actually have arming distances.
The game also expands the battlefield with another class of vessels, submarines are playable and introduce a new threat to BBs and lone carriers while expanding the duty of DDs and CLs to submarine warfare.

It's of course not without flaws, It is certainly a bit uglier than WoWs though it easily beats NF, but that's not really a challenge (not talking about NF2, nobody talks about NF2). There are only NA servers available, so I have to play with a rather high ping of 120 to 200 from central europe. And the UI is not the cleanest design around.

That said, it's free. So if you're interested in a (F2P) naval arcade combat game, just download it and sink a few ships to see if it fits you and judge yourself if you like it more than its competitors or not.

reviewText:
You should play this game for it's utterly ridiculous profanity filter. You cannot hold a conversation of any length without it triggering at some point. Complaining about someone suiciding on your team? Can't. Suicide is a bad word. Want to complain about passive-aggressive behavior? Good luck: Passive is a bad word... because it contains '♥♥♥'. Absurdity reaches a pitched fever when you try to describe a map in a naval warfare game and it pukes on you for using the word 'canal'. Not that this is any of a surprise... China is good at exactly two things: Censoring the **** out of everything and producing lead-infused childrens' toys.

Which leads me to the game itself: The gameplay itself is about as fun as lead poisoning. The map selection is small. Submarines and carriers are severely underpowered, and battleships can be easily sunk by one or two torpedoes... as long as you spend money to get the gold-plated versions. Regular versions require about 4 torpedoes to sink one. And destroyers and cruisers can launch 4-8 of these, so you're still pretty screwed even without the Credit Card Ultimate Upgrade(tm).

The carriers are cursed with planes that are easily shot down, can be seen at over three times the distance they can spot at, and as a courtesy, fly low, slow, and in straight lines or hopelessly long and predictable semi-circles. And the torpedo-dropping ones even helpfully do a full circle about the release point before dropping most of the time. Basically, you have to be asleep at the keyboard to be damaged by a plane, and this assumes you didn't faceplant onto the W" key and aren't completely stationary. Even at that

reviewText:
Is this a copy of World of Warships?  No, it's better.  Here's why:

+ Gunnery requires skill.  The longer you aim, the more accurate the guns will become.  Turning the vessel even a little bit will spoil your aim, as it should be.

+ Torpedoes also require skill to use; there's no overlay telling you exactly when and where to shoot torps.  If you want to slam an entire volley of fish from your DD into a battleship, you'll need to get close to it.  A BB's secondaries can rake you hard if you do.  Which brings up...

+ Direct control of secondaries!  See Wargaming?  That wasn't so hard, was it?  Direct control of AA guns, as well.

+ Big tech trees for three nations.  Two more placeholders.  Far more ships here than in WoWS.

+ Submarines!  See Wargaming?  That wasn't so hard, was it?  And depth charges, too.  A couple of DDs taking it to a submerged u-boat is great fun.  This gives the DDs a really imporant role in fleet engagements, as a sub getting in close to your battleline or carriers can wreak havoc in very short order.

+ Battleships don't suck.  They actually have useful armor.  DDs and CLs can't just hang back and flamethrower a BB to death.  Small caliber artillery will bounce off of a BB's armor belt, though you can penetrate their thinly-armored decks if you can finagle a hit on them.  Your best bet is to close to torp range in a group.   Make no mistake:  a single DD is quite capable of ruining a BB's day if she gets in under the guns.

+ Battleship main batteries hit HARD.  If you land a solid volley on a non-capital vessel, it's toast.

+ More advanced crew management.  There are a lot of different crewmen with a huge variety of activated skills, and they acquire more skills with experience.  It's almost RPG-ish in nature.

+ Detailed equipment and consumables in a large variety.

+ World of Tanks style vessel progression.  You upgrade individual parts of the ship as you wish.

+ There's a very unique investment" system
date: whereby you can invest gold in your future progression
recommended: which will pay off with interest as you unlock higher tiers.\n\n+ A renown system which you can play to increase your rank.  Rewards are given out at the end of each "season" based upon the rank you achieve.  Better play increases your rank
hoursPlayed:
and vice versa.

+ Buy gold direct through the Steam wallet.  This puts a layer of security between you and the foreign game company.


In short

先说结论，我要给这游戏差评。
当然，和Steam上烂大街的画质/优化节奏大师不一样，我们不提这游戏的画质（虽然它确实一般）。
Steel Ocean，或者让我们提起它的本名，《海战世界》，这是搜狐畅游旗下的游戏。说实话，光是看到这个公司名我就已经瑟瑟发抖，不过具体的黑历史我们还是不提了。
海战世界顾名思义，是一款海面载具射击游戏，也就是船。但是如果你说它是WG旗下《战舰世界》的抄袭游戏，那我可要反对了。它怎么会是抄袭《战舰世界》？
人家抄的是《坦克世界》！

海战世界在游戏体验上有致命缺陷，让你清楚的感觉到你玩的不是一艘船。
首先，船体的操控灵活度就有问题，你能够很轻易的减速和倒退，惯性作用很小，因此你能够做出隔山伸缩流之类的玩法来，这是在海战中绝对不会发生的事情。
其次，火控机制也是非常糟糕的部分。海战世界直接复制了坦克世界里自行火炮的瞄准机制，不仅鹰眼视角是如此，第三人称视角居然也是如此！想象一下十几艘战列舰停在战场中间互相等缩圈，真是壮观。
畅游下了不少功夫在宣传潜艇上，然而他们恐怕不知道怎么做好水下场景，于是他们选择了——不做！潜艇像是直接贴在水面下几十米的地方。说实话猎杀潜航之类的游戏虽然水底场景做的不是很好，但是好歹能看，你这潜艇直接“浮”在海底不太好吧。不论画面，潜艇的平衡性也一直有很大问题，相比起它的输出能力，其他舰艇的反潜能力实在太弱，导致很多事情潜艇都非常OP。

当然，要说《海战世界》我们还是不得不说它神奇的指挥官系统。这游戏有很多不同的指挥官，各自有不同的技能加成，其中有一些的技能可以说是史诗级别的强力。
那么在哪里才能买到呢？商店里么？
不！你根本不能“买”到指挥官，你需要抽！俗话说的好，充钱才能变强，但是现在你充钱也不一定能变强了，真是开心啊。可以说我还是第一次见到MMORPG以外的游戏用抽奖系统，而且还是这么直接，这么露骨的用手游式的扭蛋系统。

不是给WG打广告，我是正统WG黑，然而这个游戏真心连战舰世界都不如，好歹战舰世界还有点船的样子。
最早的时候我还是对这游戏有点盼头的，因为刚玩过千岛湖世界感觉比较失望，指望这游戏能够改变一些。然而我还是太天真了，游戏机制从开测到现在还是没什么改变，这样子只能是自己坑自己了。
当然，Steam上还是有不少国产游戏的，很多独立游戏也能看出制作者花了不少心血。但是这堆商业游戏，尤其是准备上Steam的仙剑6，你问我滋不滋磁？我只能说，亦可赛艇！"

reviewText: I hardly play subs and let me start off with this game made me uninstall World of Warships for many reasons.\n\nThis game has a lot more variety and better defined roles for ships rather than a stupid rock, paper, scissors rush game. Carriers are effective and Battleships can play like their real life versions and lob powerful rounds up and over their allies to deal heavy damage to enemies. Destroyers also aren't nearly invisible ships with lightning fast torps, and Subs are hard countered by Destroyers and light countered by Light Cruisers. The different types of ships are fast and easy to unlock also, not pushing you into a redicolous grind through several different types of ships through multiple tiers for a single damn Carrier. The playerbase is lack luster and teammates are almost assuredly going to not do their job in specific ships, such as sub hunting in destroyers, but I'm sure that it'll change as more and more people are exposed to this game. The premium aspects aren't nearly as powerful as people say it is. It's hardly, if at all, noticable. J

reviewText:
To everyone reading this, dont base this off World of Warships. Its as far away from World of Warships as you can get (And Tone isnt an effin premium like those money vampires in St. Petersburg...). So here's 10 reasons SO is better than WoWS.

1) Most of the ships arent paper designs.
While you have things like the Illinois-class, Kongo Prototype, Nagato Prototype, and the H-classes, they only represent a small amount of ships (I can probably count them on the 15 fingers on each hand of an Agent Orange baby), the significant majority of the ships there are realistic, and some have specific years to designate how old/outdated their technology is compared to their modernized versions (Like for instance, Furutaka (1921) won't have the same statistics as the Furutaka in World of Warships, which has multiple hulls depicting multiple years modernizations took place (Or in WoWS Paper ship terms, different designs)), and most ships are balanced by what they possessed in terms of firepower, speed, and overall difficulty to wield (For instance, Pensacola is Tier 5 whereas Cleveland is Tier 8 in SO, meanwhile in World of Warships, because Pensacosta is apparently a better upgrade, Cleveland is Tier 6 and Pensacola is Tier 7).

2) Graphics
Im gonna cut right to the chase, the graphics in this arent the best...and they arent really Triple-A game worthy, but then again, look at WoWS graphics...they arent exactly Crysis 3-level graphics...

3) Speed of the matches
This one is a fun one. SO feels much quicker to get to the enemy, leaving less time to plan and read your favorite Bible Book while your R key does the rest like in WoWS. In SO, you get to the middle of the map much quicker (Possibly due to the small map size?), and it doesnt give you much time to ♥♥♥♥ around getting lost like in WoWS.

4) Submarines
I haven't played them yet, but they look interesting to say the least. From what Ive seen (And not PhlyDaily, if I could find a blade that's edgier than him, Id be the luckiest man on Earth), the Oxygen forces you to make choices that will affect your chances of survival by being forced to the surface every couple of moments to replenish oxygen, and a single torpedo hitting you will probably sink you. With the inclusion of the...oh wait Ill mention that next, with the next function, it pretty much balances the Sub out in terms of no Sneeki Breeki Iv Damke for you!

5) Torpedo safe-zone
Who knew that including a safe-zone from torpedos can help balance a game! I BET THOSE GUYS AT WARGAMING NEVER THOUGHT ABOUT THAT...

6) Battleships
Battleships seem to be actually worth the EXP in this game, whereas Heavy Cruisers always dominate WoWS to no end. BBs now have the ability to absolutely destwoy enemy ships with a single salvo, ranging from other BBs to HCs to LCs to CVs, and everything inbetween. For once I can actually go to enjoy Based Nagato /o_o/

7) Gold is...much more expensive...
While WG is pretty greedy, this game is even more greedy, in terms of the amount of gold you can buy...though to be fair, the 311 USD deal (Nice try goyims) is much better than WG if they tried a 1 dollar = 250 gold conversion (77758 (Rounded up) from WG compared to 155,500 (Plus 155,500 for your first purchase) by SO) for 311 USD.

8) LOTS of ships
SO has many historical ships that actually served in the Pacific and Atlantic Theatres, including most of the ships from BS:P (Which would be the closest match in terms of amount of historical ships), and they dont try to add names to ships THAT NEVER HAD NAMES,

9) Gun reload times.
My Tenryuu in WoWS had a 5 second reload time on its 14cm guns. In SO is 12 seconds. Which do you think is the most realistic. Take your pick. Choose your poison. Whichever suits your fancy. SO is more realistic. Whatever floats your boat. Or sinks it.

10) There's a tutorial that allows you to get into the game.
In WoWS, you dont really get any introduction, and you're essentially told Go out there and shoot at things." This would be fine if they told you what exactly you're supposed to do and expect from the weapons you have at your disposal. SO's got you covered.

Id rate it a solid Star Destroyer/USS Iowa"

reviewText:
Steel Ocean: A More Advanced WoWS for the Less Windowlicker-grade Members of Humanity
To preface this - I have been playing World of Warships since the Closed Alpha test, which while insanely fun and enjoyable experience - slowly turned to garbage as development advanced, and Wargaming continued dipping their filthy, vodka-coated hands into the WoWS pie. WoWS slowly became an unbalanced, overly-simplistic, insanely unenjoyable and mundane experience wherein Wargaming plays the usual role of being 100% incompetent at development, community skills (this includes listening to the playerbase more than literally never.), and balance. Now, I do not want to say I hate WoWS - but after playing this game, I find it increasingly more hard to root about for reasons to play WoWS more often than one or two matches.

To also give you perspective, I am an AVID Aircraft Carrier fan. I love my Japanese CV's, and was heartbroken to find that they were implemented in WoWS in such a laughably bad way. (Better torpedo bombers and more active wings simultaneously at the cost of less planes per wing, and useless fighters.) While this was acceptable for a short while, it increasingly grew more and more unbearable; patch after patch, faulty rebalance after faulty rebalance - and Japanese Carriers no longer had a purpose, with inferior fighters and torpedoes that have virtually no chance to cause flooding (easily neutering the warship), and coupled with new meta that arose wherein USN CV's use their numeric superiority of fighters to shoot down all opposition and then proverbially squat atop the enemy carrier and ♥♥♥♥ on the captain's head - I lost all remaining faith in Wargaming and had decided to quit playing WoWS to find new horizons.

After Navyfield 2 failed in such an awful matter, I really needed to find a new game to play that was a naval combat MMO - and I was insanely lucky when my friend just so happened to link this game as a joke. A Chinese knockoff of World of Warships that is supposedly better than WoWS. After beating a dead horse and nagging at my friend about how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ WoWS is, I realized the futility of this and waited for Steel Ocean to be released. While the release slipped my mind at first, I recalled the game, downloaded it, and much to my shock and awe - played an infinitely better naval combat than World of Warships.

To begin - let us list the negatives, of which this game has surprisingly few.

Cons:

Absolutely heinous graphical performance. Both in literal performance and graphical appeal. The game runs poorly on my computer despite the game looking like it was made in 2008. (AMD HD Radeon 6970 Sapphire Dual-X)

The community understandibly, yet bafflingly seems completely braindead. Frequent teamkills, no idea as to what to do, useless Battleships not moving an inch from spawn, Carriers suiciding off into the enemy team. (Hopefully a meta begins to float around to shine light on what to do.)

Map sizes either seem small, or Destroyers awfully fast. Granted, this might be an error entirely on my fault - but I can't help but feel like a few maps are far too easy to traverse for DD's and ends in a Battleship's untimely death. (Either that or superior captaining, I'll just leave that up to the playerbase.)

Mediocre UI elements. Such as a lack of grouping carrier-based aircraft together, clunky tabs, and awkward management of the tech tree.

Cringey voices for pilots, crew, captain, et cetera. An option for national crews would be amazing. (Japanese voiceovers for the IJN, German for the KM, accented English for the RN, et cetera.)

Pros:

Much more advanced and intense gameplay. Requiring you to micromanage aircraft significantly more (this includes assaulting with dive bombers and torpedoes; requiring you to manually set the path of assault and correcting it to compensate for movement, potential turning, and to avoid AA density. As well as the removal of EZ-mode aim assist, and a lot of UI elements that made WoWS far too simple to play. (Lead indicators, shell impact time estimates, auto torpedo and bomb drop, et cetera.)

CUSTOM AIRCRAFT CARRIER LOADOUTS. This is the biggest point for me. This, this right here makes Carriers so much more damn fun. No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gimmicks, no assymetrical balance"
date: no preset loadouts - the ability to customize and tailor your aircraft carrier to fit your needs and wants. I love this so much.\n\nCONTROLLABLE SECONDARIES

reviewText:
To gain a greater appreciation for this review, let me roll the calendar year back 3 years, to the last quarter of 2012 when I signed into the World of Warships forum.
-
At this point, my first impressions of the community in its infancy was relatively positive, largely due to the objective nature of both the users and the developers.  Granted, there was very little information regarding the status of the game development, however, there was sense of community that our input was being received, and to some degree, acted upon.  One of the discussion that surfaced was the inclusion of submarines, and while the community embraced the possibility of testing said model, behind the scenes that topic had been shelved, and forgotten.  The community on the other hand, frequently raised the question, to which either mods were instructed to avoid it altogether, or Wargaming simply did not respond.
-
Eventually, as the game developed, Closed testing began, the truth of there being no subs came to life in a very public manner with Wargaming’s own spokesman stating ‘there will be no subs in the game’, and other statements regarding how they don’t fit in the game – period.
-
I have been a Closed Alpha tester for World of Warships, and from the very first day I signed up in 2012, I have always maintained that submarines do fit, and properly balanced, the game would attract every possible sort of player.  Of course, this didn’t sit well with those carrying water for the devs, nor for anyone else for that matter, that aligned themselves with the status quo.
-
For them, it was a creative decision.  For the fans, it would be a marketing disaster waiting to happen.
-
In enters, Steel Ocean.
-
From a pure standpoint of marketing, this title brings relief to a specific market, players that have conceded that WoWs was the only fruit in the vineyard, the only game that provided some soft resemblance of our long departed Navy Field, and settled for WoWs.  In the back of mind, playing destroyers in a limited role, there was always that desire to use the fan tail, drop depth charges, chase submarines, and fully embrace naval combat both in surface warfare, and Anti Sub Warfare.
-
Steel Ocean delivers on all these points, and then some.
-
Not only is the gameplay fluid, dynamic, and challenging, the game provides every possible component that a full-cycle player would want, from diving to avoid bombers and torps, to hiding and ambushing passing ships, the game excels in these regards.
-
The balance consideration is perfect, giving submarine commanders’ room to risk it all on the surface, dive to avoid contact, and lay in wait for an unsuspecting enemy contact.  There is a sense of drama that is what inspires many sub drivers to play this role, the challenge of supporting a push, guarding a choke point, or watching the base.  Besides these points, the full spectrum experience of having the ability to engage the enemy on the surface, below the surface, adds so much more strategic and tactical reasoning to the game, something the developers took time to develop, and get it right.
-
For me, the simple inclusion of submarines into a massive player online experience is the icing on the cake.  For me, Steel Ocean is now my harbor away from home, preparing my submarine for combat, and having a place to have my cake, and eat it, too.
-
Well done.

reviewText:
This is not a bad game at all. If you enjoyed playing Battlestations Pacific or Navyfield, then you should be right at home with this game.

First off the cons:
The UI is clunky. Let's face it, there are just a huge amount of tabs to sort through and when you are playing carriers there is no way to group together aircraft or zoom out the map and give pathing orders.  Also, when you are firing your cannons in the traditional scoped view, you have to constantly adjust and readjust with jerky camera movements. The lack of gun plane stabilization like that which is present in World of Warships (x key) is annoying but really hurts destroyers and cruisers.

Average graphics. World of Warships (the main game that this will be compared to) definitely has better visual fidelity. The models are not exactly to scale which is sometimes jarring but this is more than made up for by the vast features Steel Ocean brings to the table.

Poor optimization. I play on laptop with an i5-5200u and HD5500 igpu and I just barely get 30fps (mostly around 20fps) with the settings on low. World of warships always stays above 30fps in the 40s however with all the torpedo particles and gunfire effects there is probably good reason for the slowdown. Especially torpedoes, I get frame drops when I use those.

Low tier balance issues. Playing cruisers at low tiers will give you an awful grind. You will get pounded from long range by battleships that out-range you by quite a bit. Also Battleships tend to keep in the back of the map so you will have to go through the front line of submarines to get them.

Now for the pros:

Submarines! The main selling point of the game, you can submerge and surface to avoid gunfire however with a large penalty to movement speed. Subs are very fragile but if you can sneak up on a carrier or battleship, you will definitely rebalance them. There are two dive states; shallow depth and crash depth. At shallow depth you can still fire your torpedoes and your oxygen (time allowed to stay submerged) will depleted slowly. You are still vulnerable to air and ship launched torpedos as well as depth charges. At crash depth nothing will be able to hit you except depth charges, so use this to dodge torpedos and try to stay clear of cruisers and destroyers.

Each class of ship has a clear defined role. Like rock, paper, scissors, Steel Ocean has multiple classes of ships that are very effective against each other. Battleships will tear up cruisers like butter from long-range, while submarines prowl the seas for that lone BB and send him to Davey Jones Locker. Destroyers are fast and maneuverable with lots of torpedoes, high sonar capabilities, and depth charges(anti-sub). Cruisers are bigger and better armed than destroyers but are less maneuverable and have more of a difficult time landing depth charges on subs(anti-DD). Carriers are the jack of all trades, they can effectively sink shallow depth submarines and pose a large threat to battleships. Carriers are limited by a poor UI however, and you can only assign a maximum of 5 planes in one air group (you get multiple air groups). Manual AA fire is also very effective against planes.

You can control your secondary armament and AA fire! Are you tired of playing a horrible underpowered Kawachi with useless secondaries in World of Warships? Fear not! You can control all 14 of those devastating 152mm sponsoon guns and seriously harm any marauding destroyers. Dislike those scouts or fighter planes lighting up your position? Open fire with all guns blazing and shoot down those planes knowing that it is your aiming skill and not the ai doing the work!

Steel Oceans has great potential as a Battlestations/Navyfield hybrid and could pose a threat to WoWs with proper optimization and a UI overhaul. Proper team play is very effective with designated roles, however like your average tomato WOT or WoWs player, you will not see coordination that often. Hunting for subs and battleships in submarine wolfpack is great fun and it is incredibly satisfying to know that those torpedoes you launched were from your skill alone. (NO aim assist for torpedoes) With time I think this game will truly start to shine, it just needs a bit of polish.

reviewText:
I am really pleased with this game.  I am a longtime World of Tanks (WoT) player, and played about 1000 games in World of Warships (WoWS) since last fall.  I really love naval history, and tried my absolute best to enjoy World of Warships.  But then I found Steel Ocean...

I uninstalled and reinstalled WoWS about 8 times over the last 6 months.  Why?  Becuase as much as I loved the concept, I felt that Wargaming (WG) just could not fix fun-killing aspects in gameplay.  Additionally, there was a critical lack of content: WoWS has been out just a couple months longer than Steel Ocean, yet there is still no Royal Navy tech tree, and no German battleships.

Steel Ocean solved both problems for me: The gameplay is faster and more dynamic, the matches are more fast-paced and stress-free, and there is a wealth of content that bodes well for the future.

Let's talk about the gameplay first, and how it is better than WoWS.

For me, WoWS really dropped the ball on aiming.  In that game, you can learn how to lead targets and know exactly where to hit a ship (ie, the citadel), but then RNG takes over and sends your shells into the water around the target.  It is incredibly frustrating and depressing.  Steel Ocean, by contrast, uses the World of Tanks-style aiming circle, which allows you to use your skill much more in aiming: Take the time to aim properly, and you will hit hard.  That is a much better system in my opinion than aiming correctly and saying a prayer to the RNG gods before you click.

Steel Ocean also features faster games.  One of my constant gripes about WoWS was that it took forever for matches to unfold.  It was not unusual to spend 5 minutes sailing into position before firing a shot.  Furthermore, it was not unusual for matches to run the full 20 minutes.  And if you lost, you felt like you wasted a good chunk of time.

Not so in Steel Ocean: It's more of an arcade experience, and that means you get into action fast, and the action is fast once you get in it. Matches don't run more than 8-10 minutes usually, and if you lose, no big deal.  Just play another fast, action-packed match.  I find this a lot better psychologically, and I feel less pressure.

Steel Ocean has a better spotting system and it rewards spotting damage.  This allows destroyers to play their role as scouts.  In WoWS, destroyers are an utterly broken class that can see everyone while remaining invisible, then launch devastating spreads of up to 15 torpedoes at unsuspecting targets.  They spot targets for larger ships, too, but they are not rewarded for the damage these larger ships do to the spotted targets.

Steel Ocean destroyers are not the all-destroying plague that they are in WoWS.  Rather, they are part of the team, providing the spotting that the bigger ships need.  Sure, they can use torpedoes at close range.  And here is another thing that Steel Ocean does better than WoWS: You can only fire one torpedo at a time, and you have to aim them yourself.  There is no lame aim assist" for torpedoes.  Only your skill and positioning will determine if you hit.

Another problem with destroyers in WoWS was that they exploited a poor armor penetration system.  In WoWS

reviewText:
I'm an old man and  this is going to be a long and detailed review.. Hope it helps you..

About me:
I got wife, dog, very demanding job. My time is very valuable to me..

I spent around 300hrs of my life to this piece of junk game. Got ~1100 battles.. I am a decent player with excessive knowledge in naval tactics and ww2 history. Was the admiral of a fleet with real nice people.. You got the idea..

THIS GAME IS ABSOLUTE JUNK.

Onto details:

- Absolute World Of Warships rip-off which doesnt even come close..
- Unrealistic ship mechanics.. You can simply stop a frickin battleship in a heartbeat like a bicycle and evade torpedos.. All ships act like frickin UFOs.. Accelerating, decelarating and manouvering are all ridiculous..
- Horrible matchmaking.. Just horrible..
- A player base that is getting smaller and smaller.. Average matchmaking at mid level takes 5 minutes.. I remember waiting for 15 minutes for a 3vs3 t7-t8 battle.. EVERYTIME its like this.. Average number of players online 35... THIRTY FIVE... Not 100, not 1000.. THIRTY FRICKIN FIVE..
- Absolutely worst Developers ever.. They dont give the slightest f*ck about their players.. They shut people up in discussions.. They lock threads that proves there are cheaters in game or any thread that is critic of them.. ANY..
- You can cheat all you want.. There is no penalty. You can team-kill.. All day long.. Nothing will happen.. There is nothing you can do to lose your account.. The guy who openly killed teammates and gave away positions to enemy got a 12hr ban after everyone complained about it. The guy who started the discussion thread about an entire fleet cheating got shut up.. The thread got locked..
- There is a PG rated chat censor in this game that you wouldnt believe.. Apparently in China these are bad words: canal, system, speed.. the list goes on and on.. You cant write 3 sentences without triggering chat censor.. Developers of this game = LEARN ENGLISH and GET A DICTIONARY !!!
- Ship types... Oiiii weiii... The aircraft carriers are jokes.. The aircrafts are mosquitos that you wipe out by spraying lead on them with any type of ship including battleships.. LOL!!!! IN A WW2 GAME!!!!.. Would it kill you to read a history book and see the number 1 cause of why battleships were sunk in World War II?? The submarines are target practice for destroyers.. The cruisers are absolutely useless.. No power, no stability, just floating targets for battleships..

I can go on and on...
Why I played this game this long.. A very good friend was playing it too.. So for long time I stayed with him..
Then; I downloaded World Of Warships... And I stopped playing this crap the moment I played WoW.. Its the best game in the market.. GET it..

Steel Ocean IS A PIECE OF JUNK...

In a single word: REGRET... Thats what comes to my mind when I think about this game.. REGRET..

STAY A MILE AWAY... Download World Of Warships.. Have fun..

reviewText:
Do not dismiss this game as a mere WoWs clone. Yes, it is true that it is extremely similiar to WoWs at first sight, but the same could be said for the countless Minecraft-looking games out there and they are rarely dissed as rip-offs, right?

This game is much less realistic than WoWs, yet is it much more fun than WoWs.

+You control all of the weaponry on your vessel. The minimum number of weapons you will have at your command is 2, which is the maximum number in WoWs.

+You can use AA guns, you can use depth charges, you can use the battleship's secondaries.

+All this versatility creates an added value when you're driving relatively slow vehicles such as ships. You won't be waiting for reloads more than you shoot.

+Subs are fun not just for sub users, but also for sub hunters. It's extremely satisfying to dodge a sub's torps and see it desperately try to run away as you close in for a depth charge attack.

+Battleships are super fun. Your main armament covers almost all of the map, but aims very slow. You'll find yourself sitting in the back and raining shells over extreme ranges, and switch to fast reloading secondaries when an enemy closes in.

+No aim indicators for torpedoes, neither when launching nor when dodging. It's much more skill based here.

+Salvoes don't fall short and long at the same time and magically miss your target in a perfectly aimed shot unlike they usually tend to do in WoWs.

-/+ Graphics aren't great, but who cares? They're not bad either.

- Ship handling is simply funny. They brake like cars and reverse very easily. It's sometimes easier to stop when you detect an incoming torpedo salvo rather than try to angle your ship.


I've never even once thought of investing money into WoWs. I'm already considering it for this game.

reviewText:
Right off the bat, gonna settle the WoWs vs SO debate - WoWs is like Apple phones (easy to learn to use, stable), and SO is like Android (much more in-depth, greater customization, buggy).

Alright, now that that's taken care of, let me list some pros and cons.

PROS:
1) More customization (modifying crew)
2) More control (you can control your AA and secondary guns manually)
3) Submarines. Need I say more? (they're hella fun though)
4) CV (aircraft carrier) plane system is much more forgiving and allows much more freedom than the WoWs equivalent
5) Premium ammo is very well balanced (unlike WoT...)

CONS:
1) As of now, only NA (North American) servers, meaning eastern/mid Europeans should expect around 200 ping
2) This game is still early in development, so has quite a few bugs and pingspikes
3) Due to the fact that this game was originally for China only and that server's now closed, the current server is filled with asians. And russians. Oh boy, seen so many ♥♥♥♥ blyat idi naxuj" already...
4) Some roles (mainly DDs and CLs) are quite heavily restricted because of their low caliber guns dealing slim to none damage to decently armored ships (yes

reviewText:
My first experience with this style of game was World of Tanks.  When the developers of that game announced that there was going to be a similar game that dealt with ship combat, I was very excited.  However, after playing World of Warships I found that game lacking in several respects.  Most noticably was with regards to battleships.  After losing interest with it, I had hoped to find something more engaging, more complex and more historical in it's feel.  Well, Steel Ocean is it!  It is what I envisioned for WoW, and then some!  Here are some specifics:

1) All ships have access to their full armament, including main batteries, secondary batteries, anti-aircraft guns, torpedos and even depth charges!  The weapons seem to be reasonably historically accurate, and the access to secondary batteries makes battleships absolutely devistating if you learn how to use them well!

2) Submarines!  These are in the game and done very well.  They are both playable, dangerous, and also very vulnerable if used badly!  You have the ability to operate at a shallow depth (equivalent to periscope depth) or dive deep.  Each depth has plusses and minuses, and you have to watch your oxygen and surface when it runs low.  Very nicely balanced and a great addition to the game.

3) Light and Heavy Cruisers!  The developers were smart enough to split cruisers into their real-life categories.  Much better than lumping them all together!

4) Night combat!!!  This is my favorite, favorite feature!  You have access to starshells and spotlights!  Too bad they don't have a historical map of Iron Bottom Sound...  If they did, I'd be in heaven!  Regardless, night combat is VERY VERY fun!

5) Better tech trees.  This may be totally subjective, but it seemed as if the tech trees are composed of better ship selections.  I'm still hoping they add more, but I am very happy with the selections for both the US Navy and Imperial Japanese Navy.  Also, I'm not seeing the changes that WoW felt necessary to balance the game - for example, the fictitious float versions of fighter aircraft that they added to between-the-wars ships to balance out their lack of AA.  Although a float claude" was an attractive invention
date: it is totally developer fantasy - nothing else.\n\nOkay
recommended: so I've given you a lot of upsides.  In fairness
hoursPlayed: I'll give you the few downsides I've found:\n\n1)  The graphics

reviewText:
I'll try to keep this relatively short.


Pros: Fun gameplay
You can actually control you AA and secondaries.
More ship variety than wows and battlestations.
Limited ammo.
Scout planes can be controlled.
Games are fast and rewarding.
Has subs, which are countered by destroyers and light cruisers. Subs can also only stay under water for a limited time.
Game requires team work.


Cons: Poor graphics
Poor Carrier controls.
Planes have a absolutely terrible spotting range. (Your planes pretty much have to be on top of the ships to see them)
Server currently seems to have some ping issues for some players.
Has world of tanks artillery aim which means you have to stop to kill something accurately.
HAVE to hold down w to keep moving, you cant set your speed like you can in wows.
Lack of auto pilot for carriers.
Lack of players beyond tier 4
Your medium to long range AA does not fire automatically, you have to manually fire them. Same goes for secondaries. It's hard trying to control planes while firing your secondaries at the same time.

Overpriced premiums.
Generally poor ship controls. Needs improvement.

Lot of other things I could mention.

Game has potential, but will die quickly if things arent improved.

Game also needs a engine upgrade.

Do I recommend this game? Yes and no.

reviewText:
I love the concept and for the most part, the gameplay but I can tell it's still in beta.

Pros:
- Large amount of content
- Excellent market system as opposed to *cough* wargaming *cough*
- built-in Voice and Teamchat
- actually USEFUL roles for all classes
- Great tutorial system

Cons:
- It's a beta, and the population is still growing
- The steering and camera and scaling needs some work; DDs are too responsive and other classes, not so much
- Unreal Engine 3 is past its prime, but it works so I ain't complaining
- Devastating secondaries and AA guns. A Houshou I couldn't even spot shot down 6 aircraft before i got them in range
- Edit: the Matchmaking is currently a work in progress, t3 and onwards is quite restrictive with tiers, and not many people are playing them either.

Other/Speculation:
- From looking at the tech tree, the grind seems long, however I am unsure if xp scales to level.

Do I recommend this over other games such as WoWS? Yes, it's a unique experience and more arcadey and FUN.
I'll edit this review as I progress through the game.

reviewText:
Takes some getting used to, after having played World of warships since its closed beta.

However even dispite its dated graphics, the gameplay is so much more fun. Especially going higher tier(bout tier 4-5 is where it really starts to shine).

Pros:

-More control over your ship (I'm talking weapons systems but also more indepth repair systems then wow)
-More ship classes ( not just subs, but a clear distinction between light and heavy cruisers)
-Action packed (gotta stay sharp, danger from all sides!. One or two bad moves and you're toast...praying to a RNG god wont save you here!!.)

Cons:

-crew system while very indepth, is also confusing.
-Only 1 server(NA) with less then optimal ping.

reviewText:
If you are a fellow Navyfield 2 bittervet who found World of Warships to be a nasty disappointment, then I strongly suggest you try out Steel Ocean. While on the surface it seems like a poor man's WoWS, it comes around much closer to the fast-paced fun and tactical depth of NF2. And hey, at least it has subs and manual AA control, and the planes look actually convincing.

While I maintain that the best format for a tactical ship-to-ship combat game is the bird's eye view, Steel Ocean has several other qualities that make it much more fun to play than its main competition at the moment. Many of these are adapted from other games to the point that has made some people scream ripoff, but I don't care about the origin, my concern is the implementation. And this game's got it.

For one, the game's gunnery control is quite similar to the artillery view from World of Tanks. You get an aiming reticle displaying the shot deviation, and even lowly destroyers get a bird's eye gunnery view. For comparison, in WoWS many ships are limited to gunsight that's essentially fixed to the surface, making judging distances very difficult. Furthermore, WoWS reticle shows no shot deviation, so you have little idea at all where to expect your shells to land. The RNG is in both games, but in WoWS you aren't even given any clues as to how to account for it.

Perhaps most important advantage that SO has over WoWS is the ship maneuvering. In this regard SO is closer to the spirit of NF2, sacrificing simulator feeling for agility and speed. As such, ships accelerate, decelerate, and maneuver quite quickly, which keeps the action fast paced and makes it possible for weaker ships to not instantly face game over when making a single bad decision. In WoWS, ships move and accelerate very slowly, which would be fine if the game was about long-range fleet combat on the open seas - but it is not. Likewise, the turret traverse in SO is around the same as NF2, and not the lumbering, glacial movements of WoWS guns. Overall WoWS is in the uncanny valley where it is trying to be a simulator and an arcade game at the same time. Like NF2, SO doesn't have this sort of problem, because the maneuverability of the ships is more in line with the kind of combat that consists most of the gameplay.

Overall the balance seems to be pretty decent so far, although I've yet to try the submarine and carrier gameplay. Subs are perhaps too easy to spot for now, but a wolfpack can turn the game around quickly if left unchecked by escorts. The ASW weapons are powerful, but balanced by being quite difficult to aim on a competently maneuvering sub. Carrier planes aren't the instant death dealers from WoWS thanks to the manual AA weapons giving ships a decent chance of shooting them down. In comparison, especially in lower WoWS tiers torpedo bombers were nigh impossible to evade or shoot down and the only counter to carriers was other carriers.

Detection ranges are shorter than in WoWS, which I find positive because it gives smaller ships more usability as scouts, as well as increasing their survivability. Torpedoes have range that's more in line with NF2, rather than the knife-fight range of WoWS. For balance, they have a relatively long arming distance, so using them well means more than just sprinting up close and letting torps loose at point blank.

Overall, SO has gameplay that's much better thought out and balanced as a whole than that of WoWS, and I'm positive that fellow NF2 veterans will find this the game they're looking for. It's fun, more oriented on player skill, and has plentiful tactical options.

-Noba the grumpy CA guy

reviewText:
No thanks, WoWS still the better game. That being said, every time WarGaming releases a new game, clones flood the market. I have yet to see one that is in any way better than what we already have.

What I didn't like:
Terrible optimization of a now outdated game engine. Arcade feel and controls. Devs and moderators that can't actually help you. Direct copy of WarGaming's UI. One single laggy server. Tiny playerbase =/= 10-20 mn wait for a match. Ten tiers of grinding, all over again. Many maps near exactly the same.

What I did like:
More ship variety - Ships can carry more weapons, and there is more choices of ships.... For now. We all know WoWS will add more eventually.

Edit -> After giving the game some time I have come to check it out again - 4/27/2016
The only thing that has changed since writing this review is the playerbase has halved from the tiny playerbase it had before. Now even more waiting.

reviewText: The question here is: do you want a game that looks real pretty and (on paper) has the backing of a huge company like Wargaming.net OR do you want a lower budget game with much more intricate mechanics and more content yet one that looks (and runs) worse than World of Warships?\n\nThe argument really boils down to that since both games kinda want to milk your wallet. Both games indulge in premium stuff, both games are grindy and honestly if you already play Warships but are interested in something like submarines or ships generally having more options, I'd give Steel Ocean a try just to see if it scratches your itch.

reviewText:
I must admit I'm impressed; I've seen good and bad games, but this one is one of few that impressed me to this degree... negatively;
Firing Range for Yamato of below 10 km? now that's joke. Premise of this game is quite fun; unfortunatelly - performance; when torps go mad even early game, with bullets running wild performance hits are to be expected even on minimum quality levels. Aircraft Carrier combat - well; teaches you why one commander wasn't babysitting everything on actual carriers; You either become stereotypical korean when playing Starcraft [insane APM] or you get sunk and/or are sitting duck. also - accuracy of bombers increases by time they have hadd single target; logical? perhaps on long range; but not when distance difference is below 1 degree, and 'cost' of realigment forces half of your squad to actually change their course wildly.
Explosion visuals are signed apparently by Michael Bay, and it doesn't really matter where you aim; wether it's ammo magazine, fuel tank, or mostly empty space your damage will deviate very little; What really makes the difference is....
Premium Ammo - the very same thing even wargaming dropped in their newest game [World of Warships] and made available for credits in their original game [World of Tanks]. Given most of accuracy and combat from this game is clone of the WoT [not WoWs], you could expect creators of this game learned lesson of original creators but nope, not really. I won't even mention the crew compliment or rather 'commanders' who are incarnation of 'crack is cheaper' [TV tropes reference] pay to win. In hindsight I think this game was build around 'crack is cheaper' trope, and desire to get players into this mess.

I'd rather not dwell into all the examples where these 'ships' are basically reskinned tanks. I don't have all day, and I guess it'd even then be too short.

Hilariously - part of community claims this game is better because [wait for it] - it's not made by wargaming. [Not everyone mind you - some].

TL:DR
Looking for game to challenge wargaming's World of Warships [as I do]? Bad news - it's not this game.

reviewText:
With 62 hours playtime, I feel I can now give more thoughts on Steel Ocean.

Front End

It took some time to figure out where everything was, but i've started to learn about things such as the barracks and tech tree. The latter has now had the British fleet introduced meaning there are now six different paths to go down, although the French and Chinese are limited to one 'gold' ship each.

I've noticed that many people have complained about 'grinding' in this respect, or that the game is 'pay to win'. I suppose it entirely depends how much time you want to give the game. Me personally, I feel that there is enough variation in battles that I can go out there and try and earn EXP for upgrades and give myself a wide variation of fleet options, in fact I quite enjoy it. For others that won't be good enough, people naturally want to upgrade as fast as possible and will pay to do so.

Gameplay

I really like the game and play almost daily depending on how well the server wants to welcome me during a battle. The gameplay itself is good, and as someone who plays primarily as a battleship, there is something to like about the skill required to hit a moving target 5km away.

A recent update seems to have also added improvements to how the ships look when turning at high speed, with a very visible leaning motion, a nice touch. Also with the recent promised addition of the British tech tree, battles are becoming much more variable and as I have rarely been matched in the same battle type in consecutive games, the whole variation makes it more interesting for me.

Teamkillers & Community

The first problem that I have come across and something I have seen discussed widely on the forums, these 'teamkillers' seem to generally be denoted in battle by a blue name? They are basically there to mess up your day and it's something that I feel needs addressing. This is especially more relevant as I have seen discussions on forums that suggest that should you defend yourself against these people, it is at detrement to the rewards you yourself receive at the end of a battle.

It's important to note that the teamkillers I speak of are not newer users firing torpedoes without looking, which is itself is a problem but an understandable one. Teamkillers for me are ones that come in all shapes and forms, they roam the initial battle area with no purpose other than to kill you in close combat at the earliest opportunity.

It's also worth noting that any teamkiller can be reported during battle with an option specifically for reporting them for firing on teammates. However, as many of these users have had Chinese usernames and the game is seemingly developed in China, I'm not sure anything is being done, or will be done given I've seen the same names repeatedly doing the same thing without sanction.

Server

The biggest problem with Steel Ocean, presumably for users not in North America at least. Given that when loading the game, NA is the only available server, this is leading for problems that are well documented on forums. Although I cannot measure an exact percentage, i'd wager that 20% of the time, battles are unplayable due to an enormously high ping, for me at least. In a handful of cases, ping has risen to it's highest level and after 30 seconds of the battle freezing, i've been thrown out completely.

Another small portion of the time the ping rises sufficiently high that weapons cannot be discharged or the ship cannot be manoeuvred, this may manifest itself by putting you in an uncontrollable spin until the ping drops to such a level that you can regain control. The main issue for me here is that there is no discernable way to recognise it will happen, it's very random and a battle can be fine for the first 5 minutes, only to become unplayable at a key point. Equally, it can start as unplayable and then become playable after a minute or so. Other times a whole battle can pass of without a problem.

Further servers have been requested in on forums, most commonly one in the EU. This has been acknowledged a couple of times by devs and I got the impression that it was being seriously considered. Another post this morning by a dev on the forums suggests to me that it isn't being seriously considered and it's more of a problem for us than it is for them.

Overall

The gameplay and general community experience means I am still going to recommend this game, the teamkiller issue isn't enough to sway towards a non-recommendation. Server issues are swaying towards this though and should the situation get any worse than it currently is and make the game unplayable for longer periods, I'll have to consider it.

reviewText:
Before I get started, a lot of the negativity comes from my personal opinions.

This game is fun and it is like a mix between Battlestations Pacific and World of Warships. If you are familiar with Wargaming games then you'll understand how the progression system works. The graphics are decent and you are able to manually control AA guns and secondary guns.

I do not know how to feel about submarines, but they do provide a distraction for destroyers so battleships can deal damage. If you played WOWS, you know what I mean.

Gameplay is like anything other online game. You would get people going off to do their own thing and there is rarely any teamwork. But on the rare occasion that there is, it is awesome and can be quite cinematic.
One game that I remember in particular is when I was gunning down a destroyer and after it sunk, I lost most of my health from torpedoes. The torpedoes came from a submarine and the last destroyer on my team sailed back and forth screening me from torpedoes and dropped depth charges. I spent the rest of the game dodging torpedoes and the destroyer continued dropping charges until he sunk the submarine.
It might not sound too great, but it was definitely a heart racing moment to see who would win as submarines are sneaky little buggers.

Now onto what I personally don't like about this game.

The ships do not handle like ships. They do not feel like they have any weight to them. It doesn't matter what class of ship it is, they all start and stop on a dime.

The HUD can also be very confusing. There is a lot of information, but it is not marked very clearly and it is easy to mistake one indicator for something else. For those who have seen TheRussianBadger's BF4 video when he shows a satirical example of cluttered HUD, this game's HUD felt something like that.

Also, I was not able to remap my keys to exactly how I wanted them. I played many hours of WOWS and I tried to remap my keys to be similar but there were not enough options to do so.

There are also plenty of ships to choose from, but there are also a lot of ships that do not exist in this game. Such as the German H-class, Japanese A-150 class, and American Montana-class, as well as most Russian ships. I personally do not like 'paper ships' so that is a negative for me. And yes, I know WOWS is no different.

Like I said, a lot of my dislikes are my own personal opinions. Other than that, this game is not bad. If you like World War II era warships, give this game a whirl and see what you think of it.

reviewText:
This game is the only real competition to WoWS on the market...and in many ways, it is the superior game.

First, we'll start with what areas WoWS beats SO:  WoWS is prettier.  WoWS has a better grasp of the ranges involved in Naval Combat, and is slow paced enough that it feels more what you'd expect from a simulator.

Now, we'll do how SO beats WoWS:

-Less RNG dependant:  Big guns get calibrated by their crews between shots.  SO has a mechanic for this, WoWS does not.

-The gold system is better...not only can you buy packages (which, the first time you buy them, you get double the gold), but you can buy into a growth plan that has additional benefits as you level, as well as giving you back more gold than you put in over time.

-Premium time can be bought on the standard daily countdown method, or a per-battle method...meaning that if you don't have time to go into the game often, you can use the per-battle method of premium time and not feel pressured to play because your prem time is running out...meaning this game is much more accessible for casual players.

-Battle scarring is much better in SO than WoWS.

-You can fly any country's flag over any ship...you can have a Fubuki-class destroyer flying British flags, or you can have a South Carolina-class battleship flying Japanese colours, if you so desire.

-Ships, ships, and more ships.  This game has way more ships in it than WoWS.

-Fire, the eternal bane of BB's in WoWS is still in SO...but done much more realistically.  If your deck is on fire, it doesn't eat away at your survivability...the only time fire does that is if it's in something important.

-Control every major weapon on your ship.  Your main guns, your secondaries, your heaviest AA guns, torpedo launchers, and depth charge launchers.

-Subs.  This game proves that subs can work in this genre, and they work well.

-The game doesn't baby its players with a lead-indicator for torpedoes...it respects its players intellengence, assuming that people will be able to figure out how to lead enemy ships and develop torpedo strategies on their own.

-Carriers have more options to choose from for their planes, and aren't locked in with pre-set squadron arrangements.  If you want to use nothing but torpedo bombers, go ahead!  You might regret it, but you can do it.

-Unique ships, like the Ise BBV (part carrier, part battleship) and the French sub with the big cruiser guns...yes, these ships actually existed.

-Every ship can launch smoke bombs, as long as you buy the consumeable.

-Night battles, complete with flares and searchlights to seek out and illuminate your enemy.

-Maps that have vision-obscuring fog patches around Islands.

-Components to tailor your ship more towards your playstyle without sacrificing the feel of what that ship is really all about, or making it over powered.

This game has its competition beat, hands down.  While it is a faster paced game covering a smaller area when it comes to distances, it isn't overly crammed so you lose the immersion...it balances the need for direct player interaction without sacrificing too much towards the 'arcady' spectrum.

Trying to go back to WoWS after playing this feature-rich game is nearly impossible.  Being subjected to massive RNG again is intolerable.  Watching planes enter your AA field and linger for long periods of time before bombing you at their leisure is annoying.

Steel Ocean is my game of choice, and I make no bones about it.

reviewText:
Probably the best arcade PvP warship game out right now.
Lots of sastisfying moments, like firing a salvo of large guns, figuring out the perfect torpedo spread, or diving right before battleship shells land on you.

Submarines are balanced overall. Time-limited diving with a lengthy recharge, and destroyers and cruisers have depth charges that can wreck you at any tier. They can also hit you with torpedos at periscope depth. Death against unattentive battleships and carriers, though. Hard to hit while surfaced.

Battleships have a long-range view, like the slanted artillery mode in Armored Warfare. Guns are hard to aim but accuracy improves if you shoot at a single area. Lots of BB players forget to exit arty mode though and get torpedoed to death. BBs include manually operated secondary guns to hit those destroyers and such that sneak in. Can't do anything to subs except sit on them.

Carriers have some number of deck slots where you can assemble your own squadrons to send out, of scouts, fighters, tbombers or dbombers. Tbombers are not overpowered. All planes die quickly to people manually directing AA, so they're best against busy people.

Destroyers are just fun as hell.

Don't have an opinon on cruisers yet. Like bigger destroyers, so not as nimble.

reviewText:
It's good. Big guns that have big booms make a good game.

On a more serious note: Steel Ocean functions like World of Tanks, (or World of Warships more rather,) but with slightly less graphic fidelity. The player base is a little small, but the community is hoping for more members soon.

It's a free to play game, so there's no risk to you by playing it, however there are micro-transactions. In reality, they shouldn't be considered when downloading this game because all you can really do with your real-world cash is buy gold for purchasing some exclusive ships and decorating your owned vessels in game. Some argue it's pay-to-win, but really it makes no difference, at least to me.

What I like most about Steel Ocean is the fact that there is a lot less grinding for EXP and Silver when compared to the WoT games, assuming you're a decent player. It's more historically accurate, there is a diverse selection of ships and ship types from multiple factions (though there are some factions with very few ships to choose from. USA and Japan are your best bets if you want a larger selection.) The game is easy to grasp but requires at least some skill to master and a good amount of teamwork. Ensure everyone plays their roles well.

You can choose from:
- Light Cuisers
- Heavy Cruisers
- Destroyers
- Submarines
- Battleships
and
- Aircraft Carriers

So there you have it. It's an all-around good multiplayer experience. I hope you enjoy your playtime if you choose to get Steel Oceans, and if you do, I will see you on the sea of battle!

reviewText:
Look. I'm not going to say that this is the best Naval Warfare game out there. Nor am I going to say it's better than World of Warships, because I've never played it. But what I can tell you for certain is, that like all Free-To-Play games, there will be grinding, anger, censoring, tears, happiness and satisfaction.  As a new player, you'll launch the game for the first time, login and then sit on the port screen. You've got the 4 factions most games based on WW2 have; Britain, Germany, Japan and America. Along with two more possibly to be factions- France and China.

You'll go into your first game as a tier one, do a few matches and get to tier two. This is where things start to define who you are and what you want to be in this game.
For Japan and America you can choose to go down all lines - Cruiser, Battleship, Aircraft Carrier, Submarine or Destroyer. For UK - Destoryer, Battleship and Aircraft carrier.
For Germany - Crusier, Submarine and Battleship.

Choosing what to do here will determine what you do for quite some time or to the tier you want to get to. Playing this with friends is definelty a must have, however thanks" to the devs

reviewText:
I came to this game after playing WoWS for many hours, and over 1000 matches. I'm not likely to go back.

There are things that WoWS did right. The graphics are better, the engine is properly optimized, and the updates are regular and large. This is expected of a dev team with such a large budget.

And there are MORE things that SO did right! They need to work on a few things, but already they're on better footing than their competition.

Be aware, if you're coming over from WoWS, that the game will NOT hold your hand while trying to shoot. There's no target lock, and there's no lead indicator for torpedoes. This is not a bad thing though, as it adds realism to the experience, and makes skill more important than RNG.

PROS: subs, control of secondaries, control of AA, more skill/less RNG
CONS: poor optimization, little communication from devs, small player base
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
All in all a fun game though you really do have to give it a good couple of days play time to get used to it, I see all these reviews ripping into the game for being poor or a clone of WoWs that have less than an hour played and laugh to myself as they really haven't had the chance to get past tier 1 and 2 which is in my opinion where the game really starts to become fun.

Pros:
-Has subs
-Battleships actually hit like battleships
-Destroyers can't spam fires everywhere though do have multiple roles which make them more effective
-Propellers stop when your ship does and the rudder works!
-Ships have a more realistic sinking animation
-Can use all your guns i.e. Main (can choose between salvo and single fire, secondary, AA)
-Torpedo launchers fire single torpedo's instead of just salvo
-Guns don't take half an hour to turn the right way
-Faster feel to the battles
-Growth plan is a really good idea
-Your ships are not a large floating citadel though critical hits are common
-Can fit up to five players in a group
-Has a player made fleet function
-Had fleet battles and port battle function will be on its way some time in the future
-Has US, IJN as full tech trees, KM as a partial tech tree (BBs, Cruisers and subs though DD's are missing as well as the obvious CV's for Germany), some RN ships will be released soon (DD and CV),  France and Russian ship tree windows are there but only have a premium ship in them atm.
-Damage models seem fairly accurate to the ships and shell impact points to show on the ship model


Cons:
-Long load times due to smaller community
-Graphics can look a bit rough especially at lower settings
-Game does need optimized
-EU servers would be handy
-Premium ship cost is a bit on the steep side
-Silver gain could do with a boost

Suggestions:
-Game optimisation is a must, there are times when it brings my system to its knee's and that's just not fun at all.
-More game marketing would be helpful to bring in more players which will in turn reduce the battle waiting times
-I understand a company has to make money but the prices of the premium ships is a bit too steep, could do with a price reduction
-Though the nation windows are there for Russia and France I hope that there navies will also be added to the game, might also want to consider the Italian navy in this role.

reviewText:
It's like WoWS with ♥♥♥♥♥ier graphics and framerate. Includes submarines, went about as well as I expected.
Pretty much it's NavyField in 3D. If you like that, then you will probably enjoy this. If you have a 4gb graphics card, then you can expect to get 50FPS on certain maps and 5 on others. Needs a huge amount of optimising.
In addition, Aircraft Carriers are horribly balanced. They get shot down in half a second, their bombs do very little damage, and there are EXTREMELY limited controls for them. There is no grouping options, carriers have very delicate planes, to some of you this seems like heaven because they can't do anything, but to others this is a horrific balance. Essentially AA is WAY too effective, a single destroyer can swat off a squad of 9 dive bombers, and take no damage. Cruisers, Carriers, Battleships, good luck. You are going to need it. Tier 2s will obliterate entire waves in seconds, a group of people and you might as well just rush in and try to use main batteries.
Submarines are also unbalanced. The only thing in the game capable of hurting them is a Destroyer, which have god awful guns. The range of their torpedoes are long enough where they don't have to be in the front lines, they can sit in the back while the other team is totally helpless to do ANYTHING to stop them.
There are no servers for people other than North America. I live in NA, so the ping wouldn't be an issue... Right? Nah, 300+ ping spikes every few seconds. Internet isn't the issue here, friend is having it as well. Lots of people complaining about it in game.
Community is bad, people TK each other constantly with Torpedoes, whether they wanted to or if they are just totally brain dead I don't know, but every game there are 6+ blue people(People who have consistently team killed). Teams themselves are either a winning team or a losing team, there are no close battles. Chat is worse, languages you can't understand because the people have nowhere to go, again because of the servers.
There is a pay to win system in place. Gold ammo, does more damage and more penetration, costs ONLY gold(You buy this with money ONLY.) UI is confusing, new players don't understand mechanics. Tutorial explains very little, doesn't explain that there is no such thing as a friendly torpedo. Doesn't ever explain the actual ship UI.
Honestly, game has potential. But it's laggy in terms of FPS, laggy in terms of Ping, has no servers for anyone outside NA, haven't seen any moderation at all, Pay to Win already in place, Balance issues galore... It needs a lot of work. Til then, just wait and watch. Or play, it is a Free to play* game.

*unless you want to do more damage and penetration.

reviewText:
Summary: The game is pretty fun. If you like warship combat it's worth a try.  It's free afterall.  There's a good bit of variety in equipment and graphical skins/flags  for ships which offers some nice customization options.  I'll definitely be playing more of it, so thumbs up!

Going into the game I didn't expect too much.  I've watched some videos of the chinese version online.  I've played a decent amount of World of Warships (WoWs) and I really enjoy that game.  So that was the bar this game had to cross.

Graphics:

My first impression was that the graphics are slightly lower quality than WoWs.  The ship models aren't quite as good, but they do the job.  I think mainly the missing thing are post processing shaders.  In game one thing I noticed is that the damage models are somewhat more detailed.  When something gets blown up or damaged, the visual change is more pronounced.  It's not just fire and burned looks, the models show damanged, bent guns, burnt smokestacks, etc.

Ships can also be customized with various camo patters and flags.  They can be purcahsed temporarily (7 or 30 days) for a small amount of in game currency or permanently for some premium currency.  This is also a nice addition and helps the ships not all look the same.

Gameplay:

The game starts you in a tutorial, and it's pretty well done.  It does a good job of covering the basics for people who've never played a game in this genre before.  There's a few differences from WoWs, but if you've played it before, then Steel Ocean won't be too surprising.

Steel Ocean is a decent warship game.  The ships are a bit more arcade-like in their movement and feel a little less like a simulation, but not too much.  An hour or so in and it feels natural.  The aiming mechanic is good.  The reticles closing in as the guns line up gives you a good idea of when they're ready and you can fire early if you want to take a chance on the RNG messing you up wiht wide dispersion.

I haven't quite figured out the damage model yet, but cruisers have a tough time with Battleships - their armor is effective and they can tank quite a bit.

Early on everyone is in a destroyer - so expect torpedos everywhere.  That calms down a bit as people start branching into diffent ships, but torpedos definitely play a larger role in Steel Ocean than World of Warships.  You also have direct control over secondary weapons which is a nice change from WoWs.

Submarines are part of the game and can't be shot while submerged.  They can only stay under for a short time.  I haven't played one yet, but it seems they only have torpedos, so if you keep range you should be able to dodge them.  Some ships are equipped with depth charges to deal with them while they're underwater.

The default control scheme is more geared to controlling a person than a ship.  W and A control forward and back movement, but you have to hold them to continue to move forward.  R and F are the default keys for cruise control.  I would immediately rebind those to W and A as you really want to be moving most of the time and not have to hold the key down.

Another thing to pay attention to is that the guns can be set to fire all at once (salvo) or fire in single shot.  By default this is controlled by the ` key.  When you start a match the weapons will be set to salvo.  I would immediately change that to single shot, so you can use the method of firing one shot at an enemy to see where it goes before commiting all your weapons to what might be a badly aimed shot and then waiting to reload.

One immediate difference from WoWs is there are a lot of equipment options for ships.  For a variety of costs you can equip various bits of equipment like fire extinguishers, range enhancers, repair kits, to the ship.  This means that not every ship you see of the same class will be identical.  The customization aspect is a welcome addition!

There's also a good variety of ships.  The US, Japanese and German lines are well fleshed out.  The French and Chinese are mostly place holders with single premium ships for now.

Overall I think this is a welcome addition to the wargame genre.  Early on it's a little rough with so many torpedos, but once you get past the first tier of ships the game really opens up.

reviewText:
I'm on a boat!

Oh and look, theres a little metal thingy streaking towards it...I wonder what those alarms are for?

-------

I'm not going to say Steel Ocean is the best thing since WoW or other naval warfare F2P games. Because frankly, I never played those.

But I will say, Steel Ocean is fun and enjoyable. It's something I didn't expect to find in a F2P title.

There is content and playstyles for all types of gamers. If you are a rambo charging, goldfish attention span, CoD style player, you can take a destroyer or cruiser and blast things to your hearts content. You'll likely die a lot but then you normally have pretty low K/D ratios anyways.

If you are a more strategic player but you like to mix it up some, you'll love taking out a Battleship and just setting up shop on a map then grinning sadistically as your shells decimate attack routes. Then when things get in close, switching to your secondary cannons and making them regret ever approaching you.

Tactical player? Take a sub and decimate your foes from beneth the waves. Until you miss a torpedo and one comes in close enough to depth charge you.

Real strategic RTS player? Take a carrier out. Micro manage your fighter wings from behind the lines. Send bombers, fighters, and scouts up.

This game really has things for many types of gamers. Granted some are better than others. Which makes it hard to rate this game since it is more like an MMO and changes/balances all the time. Right now Carriers are a little weak. That doesn't mean you can't use them. Just gotta be even smarter with them.

The only major knocks I give this game are the fact you can't choose the gametypes to play. It's all randomized. Then the tutorials are a bit deceptive. Some of them are good, others seem to get you to spend coins or things that you earn that you might not want to spend. Granted they aren't gold coins which cost money but if you don't feel like spending something yet, you don't want a tutorial doing it for you. Keep in mind, esc button works to get out of this.

There is only one major knock that could be game ending for some. That is literally this game is highly populated in the lower tier ships but very sparse after you hit tier 5. You want to hang onto Tier IV and III vessels if you want populated games.

That all said, check it out, great time to be had and you don't have to spend a penny on it.
