reviewText:
Read a lot of comments that accuse this game to be just a clone of World of Warships but thats kind of an insult for this game in my opinion.

Sure there are some similarities like the progression system for example but it does many, many, many things just way better then WoW.
-The Gunplay requires much more aim and skill then it does in WoW

- Balance ! Matchmaker works great so far. Ship classes are 100% mirrored in 9/10 games. In 1/10 games one team has another cruiser instead of a battleship but things like Submarines or Carriers are always 1:1

-SUBMARINES ! They are well implemented. Of course they can dive but they just have a limited time under water since oxygen runs low pretty fast. There are 2 levels: 1st stage they use less oxygen, can fire torpedos themselves but get hit by torps as well. 2nd stage they can't shoot torps and neither get hit by them, only by water bombs (deep cahrges).
Submarine players really have to be patient and carefully. If you meet a Destroyer u're dead.

-Torpedos: NO AIM INDICATOR ! =WIN. Aiming torps needs practice. You have to judge the targets speed, have to split ur torps so that some will hit if target changes speed/direction and you need to get pretty close. Torp shots at ranges over 1km will probably not hit if the target recognises them.

-BUT !: Torpedos have a range minimum. If yo get to close and shoot ur torps they won't detonate.
It's a brilliant idea. Torps do massive damage but also require some skill and sometimes even pure luck to hit.

-CVs. AWESOME ! They are still strong but it's no OP killfarming machine anymore. Minimum Torp Range applies on torp bombers as well so there is a chance to evade if u pay attention. Also aiming your torpedo salvos is a bit harder then in WoW.

-AA. AA works great. CVs can't just roll their bombers into groups of ships and get away with this. AA kills planes pretty fast. Even faster when players decide to control their AA manually ! Even strikes on single ships with good AA have to be quick. Planes can't circle around ships for minutes while looking for the right anlge to place their torps. If they get into AA range they bein to die.

-Rock, Paper, Scissors. The ship classes are very well balanced. Threre is no one OP ship that can kill everything. Lone wolves won't survive long as well. You really have to play with your team. Every ship has a counterpart. For example:
-BBs are very effective against cruisers but can't do anything against a submerged submarine (they can't even see it without sonar)
-Destroyers are very strong against submarines and battleships if they manage to get close enough for torpedos.
-Cruisers are strong against DDs  ....

A lot of people don't seem to understand that by now. See a lot of cruisers and DDs rushing forward alone and get instand killed within seconds. While DDs can still try to dodge, cruisers usally are toast when they rush forward, get detected and bombarded by BBs. Doesn't mean that cruisers are weak or BBs OP, they are often just played wrong.
You really have to wrok together, know your role within the fleet and have to support each other. If DDs for example rush forward and leave their BBs behind and a hostile submarine manages to slip trough your lines and reaches the BBs it's not the fault of the BBs that they get killed (at least not only), the DDs were supposed to prevent that ;)

All in all the game is very well thought through and if u like naval games definitely worth a try.

reviewText: While technically unpolished and plagued by many of the same problems as all other online games (online gamers), Steel Ocean is a well designed game with a greater variety of engaging gameplay than competitors and the company behind it has done a good job of creating a decent business model.  What it lacks is players and that is likely to be chalked up to their lack of advertising and marketing.  They obviously struggle to communicate in English in all their statements to players.\n\nI think it adds to the charm, but will probably annoy others.  Still, it's free, made with care, and has a lot of features you won't find in it's more famous competitors such as submarines.  Give it a go.  There's little to lose and fun to be gained.

reviewText:
Before you download this game, know one thing:



You are not worthy.

Thsi game is the only game I have ever played that has made me cry tears of joy due to the sheer awesomeness.

You have not lived until you have gone one on one with another Destroyer.
You have not lived until you have charged through battle, chaos unfolding around you, to sink the target you have chosen.
You have not lived until you have heard the awe inspiring sound of a battleship firing its main cannons.
You have not lived until you have deployed your squadrons from your carrier, and jumped for joy when they succeeded or mourned their loss.
You have not lived until you have played cat and mouse with an enemy sub, hoping you find them before they find you.
You have not lived until you have listened to the epic in-battle music while you fought for your life.
You have not lived until you have shot off your guns in celebration of a victory.
You have not lived until you have reluctantly retreated from an unwinnable situation.
You have not lived until you have tasted the combat this game has to offer.

In the end, this game is a solid 9,001/10. Highly recommend download.

reviewText:
This game is really fun.

Every ship has upgrades (more damage but take a small hit on accuracy kind of things), or you can choose to save up your xp/currency to upgrade to the next tear of ship. So far there's a pretty good mix of games modes, all have the same general feel but will give you a little different way to go about playing.

For being F2P it's got some pretty sweet models of the ships and looks great. Yeah it's no AAA graphics but it's way better than I thought it would be.  I get a solid 60 fps with no issues...

There are quite a lot of ships in the game, you've got your Subs, Battle Ships, Destroyers, Aircraft Carriers, and Cruisers. All serve a different purpose and when played right it makes for some really good games (every now and then you get a Destroyer on your team that thinks he can take out a BS from 3k+ meters, as you go up in level/tier you don't get that as much anymore)

Over all I'd say this is a really fun game that I'm enjoying, seeing as it's FREE there's no reason to not try it out.

It's free...

Download and play it...

reviewText:
I'll begin by saying that I played a whole lot of War Thunder back in the day, looong before it was on Steam, and this scratches that itch nicely, while obviously being different (naval combat). The gameplay is very team focused which I really like, so it can get frustrating when your PuGs are ignorant and just doing their own thing, but that is pretty standard fare in any online multiplayer game.

Every day I'm still learning something new! You don't really realize it when you first start playing (admittedly, this is partly due to the fact that a lot of the more intricate things are not explained well, or at all) but the crew system, the spotting and assist system, the damage system...everything is actually pretty complex, well thought out,  and balanced properly. The simple fact that there are Subs available is what made me first try this over World of Warships, and I really have no desire to try World of Warships anymore now that I have experienced SO - I wouldn't really want the game play much slower, losing manual control of my secondary weapons systems, the crew system intricacies, etc. And I say that as somebody who intended to play Subs but has become more comfortable in a Destroyer and Cruiser role and have left Subs by the wayside (though they are excellent and highly recommended to those stealthy" players).

As I said
date: I've slowly gravitated towards and become pretty comfortable playing my role as a Destroyer and sometimes a Cruiser (working up the American line)
recommended: though it took some time and I certainly still make mistakes. It finally clicked after the first week or so that I really need to concentrate more on scouting instead of trying to be some kind of one-man DPS. Now that I understand more about how the Hiding Factor works and the scouting complexities (disguise

voteText: etc.)

reviewText:
Now, this review is from a World of Warships player, and will probably be ignored like the rest, but basically just a huge heads up of what to expect, and yes, I'll be giving this game another try at a later date, but I don't know if I can deal with this change of gameplay. I wanted warships, not speed boats.
This game is a thousand times quicker than Warships is. Like seriously, I was entering combat and almost teamkilled by a ♥♥♥♥♥ who came up from behind me before you would even be able to fire torpedoes at your ally in WoWS. He left me on 5% of my health with everything red and I was ♥♥♥♥♥♥.
Now, that's my huge gripe already. Torps are worse in this than Warships, and basically everyone can enter combat and before you know it, there's about 60 of them crossing the water each way. The way it plays is much different to Warships straight up, and I know, I only played one match and the tutorial, I probably don't have much credit to my review.
Now, the controls. Straight up it tells you, WASD to move. R and F for that lovely steady speed, kept at 25/50/75/100% speed, and Q and E (I think) for that stable turning so you can concentrate on the fight. R and F? Not what I liked. I'm used to that being my main movement, and so quickly, W and S became trash keys for me. It only told me this, after the tutorial and in my first fight. While I'm on it, the tutorial is 2 missions that basically say, kill these, and we'll tell you that you have limited communication range but who the hell cares what the range is, we don't. The rest of the missions were just gone for the time being and I was left stunned, coz, hey, TUTORIAL, TEACH ME YOUR GAME FULLY DAMMIT
Okay, the research tree in this is much MUCH more complex than in WoWS, but it's still the same thing really. One thing that really upset me though, after my first fight. Guess who had to pay for repairs?
Teamkilled me.
Basically, TLDR though on gameplay
It's much more fast paced, the maps are clearly smaller, and basically, it's an action packed game. I'm not a fan of this, but I do understand why people would love this, and why there's a bunch of positive reviews, and why people say It's not World of Warships dammit" but it's just WoWS with 200% speed boost and extra content.
It's a free game though

reviewText:
In many regards similar to WoWs, but currently with many more features and options.

The graphics are accetable, but could improve.

There is a p2w theme, but similar to other games of this type.

Overal I feel it is more fun to play then WoWs, specially since you have often to choose if you want to fire with high dispersion or wait and get the target circle down to a pin.

Also I love that things use ammo, so no unlimited spam of torps and also no aim assist for toprs, requires more skill, and that is good.

I think this game will give WoWs a run for its money, and at a minimum force them of their high and mighty horse and listen to the community.

reviewText:
Steel Oceans is basically Navy Field with a World of Warships makeover, which is a good thing in my opinion. Gameplay is pretty fun at early stages, so far. Screenshots and videos should give you a good idea what the game is about, I mainly decided to try it based on the screenshots, so i wont get into details why the game is fun. I do want to point out some problems, which are more of an annoyance. Firstly this game is developed by a Chinese team, and this right away tells you that it is not an AAA title:

There is a huge problem with censorship:
`Chat is heavily censored in most mindless ways that youre unable to type a sentence without modifying words. You are also limited to 1 line at the time, after which you have to wait 5 seconds before you can post in the chat again.
`They have also censored some things in the game, such as the German flag, which is not a problem in other WW2 themed games.
`Very poor English language localization
`Lack of maps and game modes.

most of these problems could be solved if proper attention to details is given, but again, this is a Chinese game so you cant expect fine details from them.

Overall 7.5/10

reviewText:
I am slowly getting into the game (I am at Tier5-6 at all different ship classes available in game as of now) and like it very much.

I am a NF (NavyField, RIP) veteran and was really awaiting another game having the same appeal. With Steel Ocean, it is definitely the best game out there that could call itself a sequel, or an improvement, to NF.

I had the chance to test NF2, which is horrible, don't even try to talk about that game. I also was holding great hopes for WoWs by Wargaming, but finally, the game doesn't really align to what I am looking for.

The game is quite a big composition of different elements inspired from various games (NF, WoT, WoWs, Battlestation) and the result is a success, in my opinion.

There was this issue in NF that the BB class was clearly OP (over-powered) and you could actually win the game quite easly just by being a skilled BB captain, the game seems far better balanced here. Especially looking at the role of DDs and CLs/CAs, which where pretty useless in NF (except for AA and anti Sub, when subs where a threat, which wasn't a huge problem most of the time).

Yes, it's a F2P, and yes, if you pay you're going to have a better ship and all then a non premium player with less play time. But I feel that you don't need much to enjoy the game. As long as you use your head, which often allows you to maximize them profits by taking good decisions, and don't wast your money on non-essential features, you can allow yourself a painless grind and enjoy playing longer in your beloved ships by not gaining too much experience (if you're not using premium).

All in all, I recommend the game, it's free, you should take a look and see for yourself.

reviewText:
I'm a veteran player of NavyField, which certainly had its ups and downs, but won me over in terms of variety of play and quick matchmaking.  When I came back to it a few years later, the community had dried up and you could no longer reliably get into a full game.

NavyField 2 dropped one day and I was ecstatic - this was the game we'd been promised for years.  Unfortunately, NavyField 2 failed to deliver.  I could write a whole negative review on NavyField 2, but trust me, it wasn't worth the hours I put into it, and judging by the experience of high-tier players, it wasn't worth their time either.

Steel Ocean is the game that NavyField 2 should have been - third person instead of isometric view, more emphasis on teamplay, giving Destroyers and Cruisers roles beyond rush the enemy

reviewText:
Honestly I can't recommend this game to anyone. The player base is ruining everything. Toxic talking on the world chat is probably not the worse thing this game has. The majority of player base literally have no idea what they are doing in game.

BB players are blind rushing to their death, or they will sit at spawn being useless to the team for the battle.
CV are just sitting there, asking to get torps.
DD, CL and SS don't bother looking around before torping killing their teamate.

Honestly, the average skill is even worse than Navyfield one, which we know is already low.

Doesn't matter if you carry the whole game for your useless team, because the team will let you down.

EDIT2: January 02, 2016

After playing the game deeply and further took the interest at understanding this game, I still stand firm. I still don't suggest this game to anyone.

The game so far is also messed up beyond all recognition when it comes to balance. In fact, it is no better than War Thunder. It is important to mention that the balance might even worse than Navyfield or World of Tanks.

The best example would be late tier Destroyer's shell outdamage to an extant some heavy cruisers and CL in this game within a gap of 1-2 Tier. Their DPM is on par with those heavy cruisers (German vs IJN DD)

The physic of this game makes a certain class completely obsolete; such as heavy cruisers.

The physic of this game gives an incredible advantage to the following class: Destroyers and CV. Here's an explanation as to why they do so.
CV: The current physic allows torpedo bombers to turn 90degree nearly in an instant, which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and basically it's a big middle finger to whoever try to dodge them.BB's, CA, and couple of CL are just food to them. Because of this, dodging is almost irrevelant against half decent CV player. The only ship class that may be able to evade them are usually the DD.

DD: The current hitbox, speed, agility, health pool allows one ship to YOLO scout in the firing range of the whole team and be able to get away. DD's survivability is insanely high. Even a BB doesn't have such equivalent. Further, it doesn't require much skill to get close in the 1-2km to a BB to torp them, and is easier if you buy the cheap smoke.
Their late tier torpedos are just a joke seriously, it takes 2-3 torps to sink most ship in the game such is the case of the Japanese (Here's where they apply nation trait in a brainless manner that just FUBAR the games).
Because of the current physic, this game should just rename to DD Ocean"

reviewText:
Product received for free

Things real mony will buy in this game

* ammo that hits much harder
* fix your ship in a battle
* skins that cause you to be unseen by radar longer
* ships that are in the wrong teir
* faster grind

Gameplay

The game works very hard to prevent you geting into many fights that are your own weight classs, it works hard to make sure you are nearly always out guned and out armored by droping you into fights where most players are the next level up to encorage players to seek the next teir of gameplay. efectivly meaning that 9 games in 10 you will be horribly out guned and 1 game in 10 you will be in such an overly strong ship the other players shells bounce off you. Matchmakeing has been made intentnaly unbalanced.

No manuel controll for guns or torpedos, no ability to set gyro angle debth or pistol type when launching torpedos even from subs.

i looked around the premium shop, did not buy anything the game recomends spending 311$ for the best value. so their you have it the hidden price tag of this game is around 300$ for a game with poor matchmakeing and no manuel controls no real ship customsation. Navy Field did it beter more then 10 years ago.

reviewText:
600+ Hours on this game, it's my most popular game on steam. That being said I am torn on how to write this review.

Pros:
Fleshed out ship lines (4 main countries UK, US, Jap, German)
Lots of perks - free premium give aways
Mechanics work well
Medium to large battles are a blast
Community is largely positive
Fleet battles make the community come together

Cons:
Devs speak minimal English which makes communication hard
They rarely post on the forums - I'm not sure if this is due to the language barrier or something else, I'd ask but...
Match Maker has difficulty at higher tiers and slow parts of the day
Population of the game is small and dropping slowly
Game mechanics are a bit frusterating if you don't bother to read the forums first

TLDR;
If you see advertising for this game, pick it up. It's a blast to play if there are people online.
If there isn't a change to advertising then this game will probably not exist in a few months =(

reviewText:
To be honest I cannot recommend this game.  THIS GAME IS UNSTABLE AND BROKEN.

I am a long time Navy Field player and this game does seem and have a feel similar to that game, but its clearly a clone of World of Tanks and World of Warships.

I will give the dev one thing, I appreciate them releasing the German KM, RN and Japanese lines first as opposed to Wargaming.nets model in which they clearly are milking you and keeping you waiting while pushing and making up Russian overpowered ships and tanks.

This game plays okay, more fast paced and arcady than the competitor.  What it does have is a very good sound track, graphics are not the best and this isn't a naval sim game or very strategic/tactical.   The translations are horrible and unless I learn to read Chinese I can't even understand the in-game mail I got.

The biggest detractor is this game is NOT STABLE.  Right out of a fresh install I get repeated disconnects from the server, often multiple disconnects per match.  This makes the game pretty much unplayable for me and a grind impossible when you DC almost every match for doing simple functions.

Another major detractor is because this game is free and arcady it has a very immature community.  Expect childish conversations, very little teamwork, plenty of TKing going on.  If you enjoy elementary school discussions then this is the place for you.  Otherwise to the old school/casual gamers who loved games like Great Naval Battles or Navy Field.  You'll get a bit of a nostalgia and something different from the Russian-bias MMORPG games, but that's it.  Nothing here is really innovative or ground breaking.

SUMMARY:
Pros:
- Bigger RN, IJN, KM and US naval trees instead of the Russian made-up/OP stuff
- Not Wargaming or Gaijin based
- Fast paced action
- Similar to other MMORPG's so its relatively easy to get into
- Better camos

Cons:
- Horrible Disconnects, even multiple disconnects for simple functions
- Outdated graphics
- Arcady action
- Terrible translations
- Very immature community that is small
- High amount of TK's

reviewText:
Game is very similar to WoWS (World of warships) but as of the time of this review, includes a ton more ships and submarines.

It's definitely worth a try, the playerbase is getting a little low since ~December 2015 but you can still find a match reliably. It's free and whatnot, why not try it out?

In this game your hand isn't held as much as in World of Warships and requires more skill when it comes to aiming + firing.

Another big plus is that you have the ability to use your secondary and AA cannons MANUALLY, wasn't that hard now was it WoWS?

I definitely reccomend this game to anyone who found that WoWS didn't feel very rewarding/too easy.

reviewText:
Steel Ocean is fun as hell and it's got a lot of... depth. Follows the War Thunder/World of Tanks etc. model , however there is one huge thing that sets it apart from the crowd: variety.

Yes, the biggest thing I love about this game is that it has a huge amount of gameplay variety compared to some of these other games.

-Destroyers (my favorite) are fast, agile, and are deadly at close range with depth charges to destroy submarines and torpedoes to take out carriers and battleships. Now, eventually the subs get smart and realize that if they surface they can avoid your depth charges and are almost too small to hit with your main guns. BUT what they don't seem to have caught on to yet, is that you can actually ram any ship smaller than you and it typically results in an instant kill, so if an enemy sub surfaces to try to escape the depth charges just smash into them.

-Cruisers are essentially larger destroyers- more health, and bigger guns. They are maneuverable enough to dodge torpedoes and are quite effective against Destroyers. Light Cruisers have depth charges, making them alright against subs, and Heavy Cruisers have main batteries making them able to punch through the armor of Battleships at long range.

-Battleships are the big guns, able to deal ridiculous amounts of damage at very long range. They are good at destroying pretty much any ship except Submarines and Destroyers which are small enough to practically ignore their volleys. Their major drawback is that they require Carriers, Destroyers, or Submarines to scout for them so that they can stay back and deal damage without getting into torpedo range.

-Submarines are the stealth hunters. They can submerge under water and become immune to most attacks, at the cost of speed and limited oxygen supply. Going just below the surface allows them to fire (and be struck by) torpedoes while avoiding cannon fire, and diving deeper makes them safe from everything except depth charges. Because they are slow while underwater and vulnerable to depth charges, they are very vulnerable to Destroyers, but extremely strong against Battleships and Carriers which basically cannot hurt them.

-Carriers are the odd ones out that don't really fall into the Rocks Paper Scissors circle. They can send scout planes all over the map, making them excellent for recon, and can harass ships with dive bombers, destroy enemy planes with fighters, and even take out subs with torpedo bombers. However, planes can be shot down fairly easy if the victim is paying attention, so they are most effective at taking out ships already engaged in combat.

What ends up happening in most matches is, the Battleships and Carriers sit back, while the Destroyers, Subs, and Cruisers usually charge in. Carriers are ironically the first to the front lines with their planes. Because Battleships are the most powerful in terms of dealing damage, the trick is to scout out the position of the enemy Battleships so that your Battleships can destroy the enemy's while yours stay hidden. Alternatively, if your Submarines can sneak past the enemy Destroyers, they can easily destroy their Battleships and Carriers as well.

Or if you like to yolo it up like me, you can just play a Destroyer and charge straight at the enemy Battleship. If you're still in one piece by the time you get close, you're going to be getting a lot of kills.

This variety makes every ship play totally differently, you really feel like you are important to your team as everyone has their own role to play. It's free and worth your time.

reviewText:
If you like Worlds of Warships or Navy Fleet 2 you will like this game, since it combines them into one game basically.

Problems?  Yes, the carriers are not balanced and you end up at lower levels becoming very frustrated. Hard to target with torpedo bombers and the enemy can shot down your aircraft very easy.  Fun if you are shooting at them though.  Problem is few people play carriers since they are so frustrating, so often you do not have a chance to shoot planes down.  The shooting is not assited like WoW, so hitting an enemy is more difficult except on aircraft.  However, the  manual aiming is something you may come to like as you play, since it demands more skill on your part.

Most serious issue?  Team Killers. Since this game is open to the entire global community communications are hindered, and there is no penaly system to discourage TKers.  They just run around torpedoing freindlys due to their sloppy game style and lack of concern.  THIS GAME NEEDS A TK PENALTY SYSTEM.  Temporary player bans for excessive TKs would be helpful.

Nice Features:  Several nice features, but one big one is in game verification windows to check for BOTS.  In game a captcha window often appears demanding you respond in so many seconds. Very nice security feature.

Currently most players are playing as destroyers, battleships, and submarines.  May alter as more high tiers develop, but currently you will see a sea full of submarines when you enter a game.

reviewText:
Alright for all those who are complaining the ships are too agile... Have you done any research? The ships are all within 2 knots of their actual speeds in the game, some are actually slower than their real life variants. Flanking was possible in naval warfare, the issue was that on open ocean- where most naval battles happened- you would have at least 5 miles of sight at any given time, making it extremely difficult to flank- but most of the flanks happening in this game occur on the island maps where people can duck out of your los with the small numerous islands.
As for an actual review to this game each ship plays so differently that I dont think 1 blanket statement would cover it so:

Aircraft carriers- A sort of crappy rts rip copy. That is not to say it isnt fun, it has to be my favorite ship class as a matter of fact, why? Because I love the RTS genre of course- it is also equipped with the best AA equipment.

Submarines- I don't believe I am the right person to be writing this portion but whatever: the submarines in this game operate in a nice way- if I had to say honestly its either them or aircraft carriers that have the highest skill cap- the submarines have to pay attention to a handful of things when they play more so than other ships- depth, oxygen, where enemies were last seen, distance from enemies, speed/oxygen/distance, when best to surface- probably the most engaging submarine play I have ever used in a game before

Battleships- ah yes WW2 the age of the battleship (technically the dawn of the aircraft carrier but whatever) this is the ship I first planned to use and with much good luck, you aim your guns safely from behind a wall of friendlies while they/scout planes figure out enemy locations. Then you lead your target and wait as the coi(cone of impact) slowly shrinks down to an acceptable size, after firing you see your rounds fly beautifully through the air to the idiot that dare expose himself to your cannons! Nearly everything hits heavily crippling the enemy/ killing them.

Destroyers + Light cruisers- these two play very similarly in my experience though honestly I havent play much of these, they rely heavily on torpedoes- have decent AA - and amongst other things can almost never be killed by the submarines- see speed and size - these two ships seem heavily reaction and observation based, if carriers and submarines are brains- destroyers and light cruisers are brawns(how fast and accurately can you react) for even a second late and that submarine we were just talking about has sunk you, not only that but you've brought shame to your fellow destroyers and cruisers >:(

Heavy Cruisers + Anything else I mightve missed- I haven't played these ships types, I fell in love with aircraft carriers and just stopped every other research tree
(lastly for all those claiming this is a copy of WoWs, no development for this would've had to been started before its announcement. In terms of UI and gameplay this is more similar to armored warfare. Lastly-lastly this game seems better balanced than wows as well as the torpedoes actually have an arming distance. Lastly-lastly-lastly this game is more realistic then wows.)

reviewText: Both WOWs and this game are NOT simulators, no matter how much the community sometimes think that they are realistic they are not. However this game does have some interesting additional features compared to WOWs (world of warships).\nIt adds submarines and the ability to control both AA and secondary guns manually. But the graphics are dated and the menus in jinglish. The physics is also a little on the poor side with ships stopping and starting like motorbikes to avoid torpedoes or camp. I do like the gun control system and aiming in comparison to WOWs though as it feels more like you are being lead a little less than WOWs system makes you feel. In WOWs I always feel like I am being cheated and my aim is being modified too much by the need to track the enemy vessel with a key and the shots seemingly acting more like guided missiles... trying so hard to reach the enemy ship or avoid it entirely depending on what wows wants to do at the time. However the things that bothers me most about this game are that the login is not secure or even password checked and the guns even on battleships seem to be limited to 5km or so compared o 20km or so in WOWs. Ships just feel like they have no mass in this game either. In short, more features but also more arcade and an engine that looks exactly the same as another dated engine. It's free so give it a go. Personally though I would prefer a game that was more simulator like than both WOWs and SO.

reviewText:
I played WOWS from Beta and loved it.

I think Steel Ocean is a better game.

Admittedly the graphics aren't quite as polished as the competition (especially the water) but the ships look fine to me during a battle and are more than pretty enough to blow up.

The things that put this above WOWS (for me):
Submarines - how easily they fit into the rest of the ship types and they work well in the game, not being too powerful or too easily countered but providing a tough challenge if you don't know what you are doing. They are a lot of fun to play.
They have a fleshed out German Navy tech tree already.
They have already added a CV and DD line of Royal Navy ships to the game (with the latest patch).
The Commander system provides an interesting bit of customisation beyond unlocking identical skills for every ship like in WOWS.
CVs don't seem as poweful, you can still get kills with your planes but it's more challenging, though you get complete freedom to launch whatever planes you want which is a nice bonus, no limits to one or two loadouts.
Being able to fire my own AA guns and Secondary batteries separately from my main batteries, a massive bonus on BBs.

There are a wide variety of maps, a number of different game types including deathmatch style Competition mode and a massive array of ships to collect. Considering the game has only been out for a month I am very opptimistic about the future and look forward to seeing what will come.

The only downside to me at the moment is the fact I have to play on a NA server meaning the lag is a bit annoying but even so the game is still playable enough and I've not had any major connection issues.

This game is fun, try it out, it's free.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game isn't as pretty as world of warships, but it is fun.

The submarines are very popular but not overpowered. They can only go underwater for a few minutes, 2 to 5 so far, and can also be damaged by torpedos. Unless they run deep, then they can only last underwater half as long. They have to spend equal time on the surface to recharge their air. Destroyers also wreck them since they are fast torpedo boats with good sonar.

It follows the normal method of world of tanks and games like it, with consumables, equipment, and upgrades. The upgrades often help out but are not make or break.

The torpedoes are faster than world of warships. They go about 60 km/h here and ships go about 10-35 km/h. There is no indicator telling you what angle you should be firing your torpedoes. The ships here also turn rather fast and can stop a lot faster than world of warships.

Carriers don't seem as strong since there is automatic AA and manual AA in this game. The machine guns will automatically shoot planes down slowly while the flak cannons can drastically improve this. You also get a lead icon if the planes get close enough. They enter a birds eye view mode to control the planes and often miss smaller ships getting near them. The bad part about the birds eye view is that you can't easily move the map around without scrolling to the edges of it or clicking on the minimap. WASD still controls your ship in birds eye view mode.

Battleships are more like artillery and can enter birds eye view to fire from long distances. They often won't see a faster ship sneak up on them to blow them up.

Light cruisers and Heavy cruisers are a good jack of all trade fit between destroyers and battleships.

Most of the english in this game is good, except for a few things on the friends list. And the game is full of asian game type log in rewards or do ♥♥♥♥ rewards.

The game does have gold rounds, but they are not very strong. The torpedoes are laughable, since they go 10% faster and do 1 more damage (like 650 to 651).

The gold rate is about $1 for 500 gold, with 6 one time buy packages that double your rate.

It has two vip modes. One is about 9 bucks or less per month for +50% more silver and exp. The other is a per game rate of 50 gold per match for +100% more silver and exp. That is 10 cents a pop and with a package is 5 cents.

Without VIP, the grind to tier 3 has been about 6 hours which is not that bad compared to some other games. I don't know how bad it will get.

It has a growth program that if you buy in before tier 5, you will get rewards for getting a tier 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8 ship. You will get about double the gold that you put in back and a lot of free experience, almost enough for researching a tier 9 ship.

There is a commander system in the game where you level up commanders to improve their predefined skills or gain access to new skills, or have to buy random commanders and merge two of the same to rank them up and get access to other predefined skills.

Over all, it is a rather decent boat game as long as you don't mind ships moving rather slowly and are ok with some arcade action in your boat game. There is even a rare first to 17 kill mode where you can respawn.

reviewText:
If not compared to any other game, Steel Ocean is all round good game with a good tutorial and intuitive controls.All Ships have an important role in aiding the team and players will have to pay a lot of attention to their surroundings. It makes a all round realistic game because it incorporates Atni Submarine Warfare like real Naval Battles. Since many people are saying it is a copy of WoWs, I'm Going to compare it with WoWs.
If Compared to WoWs, the matchmaking in Steel Ocean is fairer, The different Tiers are closer (so not an obvious power difference between Tier 2 and 3), And it has submarines which makes Aircraft carriers and battleships more vulnareble to attacks.

reviewText: First, World of Planes was made irrelavent by Warthuder. Then Warthunder added tank combat which eclipsed the 'World of X' crap Wargaming pumped out. reviewText:
The game is good, i definatly commend it.

But then it get difficult to choose between Steel Ocean and World of warship. So what are the difference?

The battles in SO do need more skills. No help for aiming guns or torpedoes and if you move too much you precision gets real bad. But ships are much much more fragile. In Wow sitting in a battleship you feel like in a fortress, here you just feel like having huge firepower. Same fire power that sink you if you get a full salvo from another battleship.
In SO the ships seem to accelerate and stop way to fast. And last, SO have freaking submarines!
Graphic wise Wow is a good step above SO even if the water feels a bit like oil.

So i recomend the game. But if you start to compare it, its a hard choice. You'll be better making your own choice trying both. They are both free and work pretty much the same way.

reviewText:
To answer the Question ... : yes this is a WoWS clone but it tries to differenciate somewhat...

Here goes my review:
This game is Goes down the path of F2P MMO battlarena with vechicles because of this you wil naturaly find allot of simularitys between WoWS and this game. But this game has more of a WoT feel to it(having to buy ammo/Dammage model). lets start with the Pros of the game ....

Pro:
-as of writing this review this game (seems) to have more ships
-Progression Seems fairly fast(if you win)
-movement of the ships feel nice(tough a bit unrealistic acceleration and decelleration)
-detailed shells (penetration values etc are listed(presumably also taken into account when shooting things i dont know if armor angle and thiner armored parts are modeled))
-Nice sounding audio
-Nice amount for detail on the map
-Theres submarines but theyr fairly well balanced(in my opinion(for those wondering about subs more below))
-The gameplay seems more enjoyable

Cons:
-Doesnt look that good
-Messy ship slection menu(in my opinion(stuff is all over the place))  (this might be due to my 4:3 screen)
-possibly overpriced gold items(assuming the games uses a conversion rate about the same as WoWS /WoT(havent checked))
-To get Crew you have to Pay gold
-allot of ships seem to be paperdesigns and/or redesigns of alredy ingame ships

Pro/Cons (fall in both categorys);
-No easy aim torpedos(this is also a con cause you got no clue where to aim so it becomes )
-No ciritical/Citadel hits

Conclusions :
its more of a WoT clone with somme WoWS stuff mixed in trying to stands its own in the F2P MMO vechiclecombat market. and i can understand it taking idea from other games cause if they work well might as well use them. and to shorten everything in this review to one description it would be: WoT(with somme WoWS mixed in) with warships and subs instead of tanks and arty. i have mixed feeling about this game and im not saying its bad but i dont recomend it either.(i put a Yes as recomendation since i found the game prety enjoyable for the time i played even tough im having a mixed feeling about it)

Scores:
for those wanting scores id give a this game a 4.5 to 6.5/10(rough estimate cause i  havent played it that much as of writing this) and WoWS a 6.5 to 7/10 as reffrence(keep in mind this is without a scoring system just on gut feeling)

SubMarines:
for those wondering about submarines ... heres how they work:
you have a oxygen bar that charges while you above watter and depending on the depth(shallow or deep)it will get used up faster.and as the oxygen gets lower you will also start moving slower(i Believe havent realy looked at the speed). you can only fire your deck gun while submerged and only use your torpedoes when in shallow watter or submerged. tough when your submerged your not safe when in shallow" depth you cans till get hit by depth charges (and i think artierly to rarely) and if you go to "deep" depth you will burn to your oxygen like anything youv ever seen. it also takes somme time to go up/down. when you press the assigned button you will get a WoW Like ability charge bar and as soon as that fils up you will start to raise or lower your depth(this part goes fairly fast tough maby a little to fast). and ontop of this submarines are only detectable via sonar when submerged. that said they seem prety balanced."

The game isn't as pretty as world of warships, but it is fun.

The submarines are very popular but not overpowered. They can only go underwater for a few minutes, 2 to 5 so far, and can also be damaged by torpedos. Unless they run deep, then they can only last underwater half as long. They have to spend equal time on the surface to recharge their air. Destroyers also wreck them since they are fast torpedo boats with good sonar.

It follows the normal method of world of tanks and games like it, with consumables, equipment, and upgrades. The upgrades often help out but are not make or break.

The torpedoes are faster than world of warships. They go about 60 km/h here and ships go about 10-35 km/h. There is no indicator telling you what angle you should be firing your torpedoes. The ships here also turn rather fast and can stop a lot faster than world of warships.

Carriers don't seem as strong since there is automatic AA and manual AA in this game. The machine guns will automatically shoot planes down slowly while the flak cannons can drastically improve this. You also get a lead icon if the planes get close enough. They enter a birds eye view mode to control the planes and often miss smaller ships getting near them. The bad part about the birds eye view is that you can't easily move the map around without scrolling to the edges of it or clicking on the minimap. WASD still controls your ship in birds eye view mode.

Battleships are more like artillery and can enter birds eye view to fire from long distances. They often won't see a faster ship sneak up on them to blow them up.

Light cruisers and Heavy cruisers are a good jack of all trade fit between destroyers and battleships.

Most of the english in this game is good, except for a few things on the friends list. And the game is full of asian game type log in rewards or do ♥♥♥♥ rewards.

The game does have gold rounds, but they are not very strong. The torpedoes are laughable, since they go 10% faster and do 1 more damage (like 650 to 651).

The gold rate is about $1 for 500 gold, with 6 one time buy packages that double your rate.

It has two vip modes. One is about 9 bucks or less per month for +50% more silver and exp. The other is a per game rate of 50 gold per match for +100% more silver and exp. That is 10 cents a pop and with a package is 5 cents.

Without VIP, the grind to tier 3 has been about 6 hours which is not that bad compared to some other games. I don't know how bad it will get.

It has a growth program that if you buy in before tier 5, you will get rewards for getting a tier 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8 ship. You will get about double the gold that you put in back and a lot of free experience, almost enough for researching a tier 9 ship.

There is a commander system in the game where you level up commanders to improve their predefined skills or gain access to new skills, or have to buy random commanders and merge two of the same to rank them up and get access to other predefined skills.

Over all, it is a rather decent boat game as long as you don't mind ships moving rather slowly and are ok with some arcade action in your boat game. There is even a rare first to 17 kill mode where you can respawn.

reviewText:
To be honest I cannot recommend this game.  THIS GAME IS UNSTABLE AND BROKEN.

I am a long time Navy Field player and this game does seem and have a feel similar to that game, but its clearly a clone of World of Tanks and World of Warships.

I will give the dev one thing, I appreciate them releasing the German KM, RN and Japanese lines first as opposed to Wargaming.nets model in which they clearly are milking you and keeping you waiting while pushing and making up Russian overpowered ships and tanks.

This game plays okay, more fast paced and arcady than the competitor.  What it does have is a very good sound track, graphics are not the best and this isn't a naval sim game or very strategic/tactical.   The translations are horrible and unless I learn to read Chinese I can't even understand the in-game mail I got.

The biggest detractor is this game is NOT STABLE.  Right out of a fresh install I get repeated disconnects from the server, often multiple disconnects per match.  This makes the game pretty much unplayable for me and a grind impossible when you DC almost every match for doing simple functions.

Another major detractor is because this game is free and arcady it has a very immature community.  Expect childish conversations, very little teamwork, plenty of TKing going on.  If you enjoy elementary school discussions then this is the place for you.  Otherwise to the old school/casual gamers who loved games like Great Naval Battles or Navy Field.  You'll get a bit of a nostalgia and something different from the Russian-bias MMORPG games, but that's it.  Nothing here is really innovative or ground breaking.

SUMMARY:
Pros:
- Bigger RN, IJN, KM and US naval trees instead of the Russian made-up/OP stuff
- Not Wargaming or Gaijin based
- Fast paced action
- Similar to other MMORPG's so its relatively easy to get into
- Better camos

Cons:
- Horrible Disconnects, even multiple disconnects for simple functions
- Outdated graphics
- Arcady action
- Terrible translations
- Very immature community that is small
- High amount of TK's

reviewText:
To answer the Question ... : yes this is a WoWS clone but it tries to differenciate somewhat...

Here goes my review:
This game is Goes down the path of F2P MMO battlarena with vechicles because of this you wil naturaly find allot of simularitys between WoWS and this game. But this game has more of a WoT feel to it(having to buy ammo/Dammage model). lets start with the Pros of the game ....

Pro:
-as of writing this review this game (seems) to have more ships
-Progression Seems fairly fast(if you win)
-movement of the ships feel nice(tough a bit unrealistic acceleration and decelleration)
-detailed shells (penetration values etc are listed(presumably also taken into account when shooting things i dont know if armor angle and thiner armored parts are modeled))
-Nice sounding audio
-Nice amount for detail on the map
-Theres submarines but theyr fairly well balanced(in my opinion(for those wondering about subs more below))
-The gameplay seems more enjoyable

Cons:
-Doesnt look that good
-Messy ship slection menu(in my opinion(stuff is all over the place))  (this might be due to my 4:3 screen)
-possibly overpriced gold items(assuming the games uses a conversion rate about the same as WoWS /WoT(havent checked))
-To get Crew you have to Pay gold
-allot of ships seem to be paperdesigns and/or redesigns of alredy ingame ships

Pro/Cons (fall in both categorys);
-No easy aim torpedos(this is also a con cause you got no clue where to aim so it becomes )
-No ciritical/Citadel hits

Conclusions :
its more of a WoT clone with somme WoWS stuff mixed in trying to stands its own in the F2P MMO vechiclecombat market. and i can understand it taking idea from other games cause if they work well might as well use them. and to shorten everything in this review to one description it would be: WoT(with somme WoWS mixed in) with warships and subs instead of tanks and arty. i have mixed feeling about this game and im not saying its bad but i dont recomend it either.(i put a Yes as recomendation since i found the game prety enjoyable for the time i played even tough im having a mixed feeling about it)

Scores:
for those wanting scores id give a this game a 4.5 to 6.5/10(rough estimate cause i  havent played it that much as of writing this) and WoWS a 6.5 to 7/10 as reffrence(keep in mind this is without a scoring system just on gut feeling)

SubMarines:
for those wondering about submarines ... heres how they work:
you have a oxygen bar that charges while you above watter and depending on the depth(shallow or deep)it will get used up faster.and as the oxygen gets lower you will also start moving slower(i Believe havent realy looked at the speed). you can only fire your deck gun while submerged and only use your torpedoes when in shallow watter or submerged. tough when your submerged your not safe when in shallow" depth you cans till get hit by depth charges (and i think artierly to rarely) and if you go to "deep" depth you will burn to your oxygen like anything youv ever seen. it also takes somme time to go up/down. when you press the assigned button you will get a WoW Like ability charge bar and as soon as that fils up you will start to raise or lower your depth(this part goes fairly fast tough maby a little to fast). and ontop of this submarines are only detectable via sonar when submerged. that said they seem prety balanced."

reviewText:
I found Steel Ocean to be a turd. It's a sopping wet, ugly turd in a squatting toilet -- so it's at least easily accessible. It's free to reach on in and grab it if you want. I should warn you that there are pay2win corn chunks in it that do offer real advantage for real money.

Positively, there are both sinkers and floaters, and you also get some pretty nice grunts when the turds unleash their fury.

Negatively, this turd has problems in that some of the nuggets should be faster than the others, but they all seem to turn and move at too similar speeds; also, reticles that only close in quickly on enemy turds when you're standing still, so there are a lot of easy turds to hit. The toilet is unoptimized too; again, it's one of those uncomfortable squatting toilets. It might be faster to do your business with one, once your business starts, but the discomfort causes the business to take forever to begin. That might be something time heals, but when you want to splash one down, the last thing you want to do is wait forever.

Mythbusters proved that you can, in fact, polish a turd. Unfortunately, in Steel Ocean's case, you'd have to wait a few years before it's petrified into something that could be polished without falling apart.

Ultimately, I advise you to flush it and move on. Something with more meat will stink up the room soon enough.

reviewText:
If you like Worlds of Warships or Navy Fleet 2 you will like this game, since it combines them into one game basically.

Problems?  Yes, the carriers are not balanced and you end up at lower levels becoming very frustrated. Hard to target with torpedo bombers and the enemy can shot down your aircraft very easy.  Fun if you are shooting at them though.  Problem is few people play carriers since they are so frustrating, so often you do not have a chance to shoot planes down.  The shooting is not assited like WoW, so hitting an enemy is more difficult except on aircraft.  However, the  manual aiming is something you may come to like as you play, since it demands more skill on your part.

Most serious issue?  Team Killers. Since this game is open to the entire global community communications are hindered, and there is no penaly system to discourage TKers.  They just run around torpedoing freindlys due to their sloppy game style and lack of concern.  THIS GAME NEEDS A TK PENALTY SYSTEM.  Temporary player bans for excessive TKs would be helpful.

Nice Features:  Several nice features, but one big one is in game verification windows to check for BOTS.  In game a captcha window often appears demanding you respond in so many seconds. Very nice security feature.

Currently most players are playing as destroyers, battleships, and submarines.  May alter as more high tiers develop, but currently you will see a sea full of submarines when you enter a game.

reviewText:
The game isn't as pretty as world of warships, but it is fun.

The submarines are very popular but not overpowered. They can only go underwater for a few minutes, 2 to 5 so far, and can also be damaged by torpedos. Unless they run deep, then they can only last underwater half as long. They have to spend equal time on the surface to recharge their air. Destroyers also wreck them since they are fast torpedo boats with good sonar.

It follows the normal method of world of tanks and games like it, with consumables, equipment, and upgrades. The upgrades often help out but are not make or break.

The torpedoes are faster than world of warships. They go about 60 km/h here and ships go about 10-35 km/h. There is no indicator telling you what angle you should be firing your torpedoes. The ships here also turn rather fast and can stop a lot faster than world of warships.

Carriers don't seem as strong since there is automatic AA and manual AA in this game. The machine guns will automatically shoot planes down slowly while the flak cannons can drastically improve this. You also get a lead icon if the planes get close enough. They enter a birds eye view mode to control the planes and often miss smaller ships getting near them. The bad part about the birds eye view is that you can't easily move the map around without scrolling to the edges of it or clicking on the minimap. WASD still controls your ship in birds eye view mode.

Battleships are more like artillery and can enter birds eye view to fire from long distances. They often won't see a faster ship sneak up on them to blow them up.

Light cruisers and Heavy cruisers are a good jack of all trade fit between destroyers and battleships.

Most of the english in this game is good, except for a few things on the friends list. And the game is full of asian game type log in rewards or do ♥♥♥♥ rewards.

The game does have gold rounds, but they are not very strong. The torpedoes are laughable, since they go 10% faster and do 1 more damage (like 650 to 651).

The gold rate is about $1 for 500 gold, with 6 one time buy packages that double your rate.

It has two vip modes. One is about 9 bucks or less per month for +50% more silver and exp. The other is a per game rate of 50 gold per match for +100% more silver and exp. That is 10 cents a pop and with a package is 5 cents.

Without VIP, the grind to tier 3 has been about 6 hours which is not that bad compared to some other games. I don't know how bad it will get.

It has a growth program that if you buy in before tier 5, you will get rewards for getting a tier 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8 ship. You will get about double the gold that you put in back and a lot of free experience, almost enough for researching a tier 9 ship.

There is a commander system in the game where you level up commanders to improve their predefined skills or gain access to new skills, or have to buy random commanders and merge two of the same to rank them up and get access to other predefined skills.

Over all, it is a rather decent boat game as long as you don't mind ships moving rather slowly and are ok with some arcade action in your boat game. There is even a rare first to 17 kill mode where you can respawn.

reviewText:
Alright for all those who are complaining the ships are too agile... Have you done any research? The ships are all within 2 knots of their actual speeds in the game, some are actually slower than their real life variants. Flanking was possible in naval warfare, the issue was that on open ocean- where most naval battles happened- you would have at least 5 miles of sight at any given time, making it extremely difficult to flank- but most of the flanks happening in this game occur on the island maps where people can duck out of your los with the small numerous islands.
As for an actual review to this game each ship plays so differently that I dont think 1 blanket statement would cover it so:

Aircraft carriers- A sort of crappy rts rip copy. That is not to say it isnt fun, it has to be my favorite ship class as a matter of fact, why? Because I love the RTS genre of course- it is also equipped with the best AA equipment.

Submarines- I don't believe I am the right person to be writing this portion but whatever: the submarines in this game operate in a nice way- if I had to say honestly its either them or aircraft carriers that have the highest skill cap- the submarines have to pay attention to a handful of things when they play more so than other ships- depth, oxygen, where enemies were last seen, distance from enemies, speed/oxygen/distance, when best to surface- probably the most engaging submarine play I have ever used in a game before

Battleships- ah yes WW2 the age of the battleship (technically the dawn of the aircraft carrier but whatever) this is the ship I first planned to use and with much good luck, you aim your guns safely from behind a wall of friendlies while they/scout planes figure out enemy locations. Then you lead your target and wait as the coi(cone of impact) slowly shrinks down to an acceptable size, after firing you see your rounds fly beautifully through the air to the idiot that dare expose himself to your cannons! Nearly everything hits heavily crippling the enemy/ killing them.

Destroyers + Light cruisers- these two play very similarly in my experience though honestly I havent play much of these, they rely heavily on torpedoes- have decent AA - and amongst other things can almost never be killed by the submarines- see speed and size - these two ships seem heavily reaction and observation based, if carriers and submarines are brains- destroyers and light cruisers are brawns(how fast and accurately can you react) for even a second late and that submarine we were just talking about has sunk you, not only that but you've brought shame to your fellow destroyers and cruisers >:(

Heavy Cruisers + Anything else I mightve missed- I haven't played these ships types, I fell in love with aircraft carriers and just stopped every other research tree
(lastly for all those claiming this is a copy of WoWs, no development for this would've had to been started before its announcement. In terms of UI and gameplay this is more similar to armored warfare. Lastly-lastly this game seems better balanced than wows as well as the torpedoes actually have an arming distance. Lastly-lastly-lastly this game is more realistic then wows.)

reviewText:
To answer the Question ... : yes this is a WoWS clone but it tries to differenciate somewhat...

Here goes my review:
This game is Goes down the path of F2P MMO battlarena with vechicles because of this you wil naturaly find allot of simularitys between WoWS and this game. But this game has more of a WoT feel to it(having to buy ammo/Dammage model). lets start with the Pros of the game ....

Pro:
-as of writing this review this game (seems) to have more ships
-Progression Seems fairly fast(if you win)
-movement of the ships feel nice(tough a bit unrealistic acceleration and decelleration)
-detailed shells (penetration values etc are listed(presumably also taken into account when shooting things i dont know if armor angle and thiner armored parts are modeled))
-Nice sounding audio
-Nice amount for detail on the map
-Theres submarines but theyr fairly well balanced(in my opinion(for those wondering about subs more below))
-The gameplay seems more enjoyable

Cons:
-Doesnt look that good
-Messy ship slection menu(in my opinion(stuff is all over the place))  (this might be due to my 4:3 screen)
-possibly overpriced gold items(assuming the games uses a conversion rate about the same as WoWS /WoT(havent checked))
-To get Crew you have to Pay gold
-allot of ships seem to be paperdesigns and/or redesigns of alredy ingame ships

Pro/Cons (fall in both categorys);
-No easy aim torpedos(this is also a con cause you got no clue where to aim so it becomes )
-No ciritical/Citadel hits

Conclusions :
its more of a WoT clone with somme WoWS stuff mixed in trying to stands its own in the F2P MMO vechiclecombat market. and i can understand it taking idea from other games cause if they work well might as well use them. and to shorten everything in this review to one description it would be: WoT(with somme WoWS mixed in) with warships and subs instead of tanks and arty. i have mixed feeling about this game and im not saying its bad but i dont recomend it either.(i put a Yes as recomendation since i found the game prety enjoyable for the time i played even tough im having a mixed feeling about it)

Scores:
for those wanting scores id give a this game a 4.5 to 6.5/10(rough estimate cause i  havent played it that much as of writing this) and WoWS a 6.5 to 7/10 as reffrence(keep in mind this is without a scoring system just on gut feeling)

SubMarines:
for those wondering about submarines ... heres how they work:
you have a oxygen bar that charges while you above watter and depending on the depth(shallow or deep)it will get used up faster.and as the oxygen gets lower you will also start moving slower(i Believe havent realy looked at the speed). you can only fire your deck gun while submerged and only use your torpedoes when in shallow watter or submerged. tough when your submerged your not safe when in shallow" depth you cans till get hit by depth charges (and i think artierly to rarely) and if you go to "deep" depth you will burn to your oxygen like anything youv ever seen. it also takes somme time to go up/down. when you press the assigned button you will get a WoW Like ability charge bar and as soon as that fils up you will start to raise or lower your depth(this part goes fairly fast tough maby a little to fast). and ontop of this submarines are only detectable via sonar when submerged. that said they seem prety balanced."

reviewText:
This is a naval game where every part of the fleet is important.

Oh, and they have British Battleships, and German Battleships. The whole line.  So yes, you can actually play sink the Bismarck!

Let me get the negative out of the way first: Visually this game is a bit dated. The ship controls are a bit arcadeish (but still fun and in a way, doesn't ruing the immersion if that makes sense.

That's it.  The rest is all positive.

This game actualy manages to get that rock paper scissors gameplay correct.  Submarines are incredibly deadly to battleships, but are countered by DDs and CLs.  DDs can wreck BBs if they get in close, but CLs tear them to pieces.  CLs and BBs are the primary targets for BBs, and the BBs main advantage (range and firepower) are modelled nicely.  CVs take a lot of skill to work right, but a tight fleet formation can ruin an air attack's day.

I like that the heavy weapons are not unlimited ammo.  You can't spam torps all the time, you have to be careful.  Torps have a minimum arming range, making suicide rushes a thing of the past.  There is no real aim assist for guns or torps, making both fair.  Heavier ships can switch to lighter secondary armament for taking on enemy light vessels and aircraft, giving a smart player a modicum of protection close in.

The game tracks your ability to help your team.  Are you a stealthy DD spotting for your fleet?  You get points and experience for that.  Radio Ranges and radar ranges become important, since if you scout too far ahead, no one will get your data, and your fleet can't rain down fire on the enemy.

Overall, the co-operative nature of the fleet based gameplay makes this a solid choice in my view.  There's tons of ships and lines to unlock, each type of ship has its own unique feel and gameplay style meaning that there should be something for everyone.  The game rewards teamwork and skill, and punishes lone wolfing (unless you are a sub, in which case that's your gameplay style).

It's frankly great fun.  I'm sure that as the playerbase keeps growing (never less then 30 seconds for a match for me)  the game will become even better with updates to the visuals.  As it stands, it's probably the most naval fun you can have these days.

reviewText:
Steel Ocean is fun as hell and it's got a lot of... depth. Follows the War Thunder/World of Tanks etc. model , however there is one huge thing that sets it apart from the crowd: variety.

Yes, the biggest thing I love about this game is that it has a huge amount of gameplay variety compared to some of these other games.

-Destroyers (my favorite) are fast, agile, and are deadly at close range with depth charges to destroy submarines and torpedoes to take out carriers and battleships. Now, eventually the subs get smart and realize that if they surface they can avoid your depth charges and are almost too small to hit with your main guns. BUT what they don't seem to have caught on to yet, is that you can actually ram any ship smaller than you and it typically results in an instant kill, so if an enemy sub surfaces to try to escape the depth charges just smash into them.

-Cruisers are essentially larger destroyers- more health, and bigger guns. They are maneuverable enough to dodge torpedoes and are quite effective against Destroyers. Light Cruisers have depth charges, making them alright against subs, and Heavy Cruisers have main batteries making them able to punch through the armor of Battleships at long range.

-Battleships are the big guns, able to deal ridiculous amounts of damage at very long range. They are good at destroying pretty much any ship except Submarines and Destroyers which are small enough to practically ignore their volleys. Their major drawback is that they require Carriers, Destroyers, or Submarines to scout for them so that they can stay back and deal damage without getting into torpedo range.

-Submarines are the stealth hunters. They can submerge under water and become immune to most attacks, at the cost of speed and limited oxygen supply. Going just below the surface allows them to fire (and be struck by) torpedoes while avoiding cannon fire, and diving deeper makes them safe from everything except depth charges. Because they are slow while underwater and vulnerable to depth charges, they are very vulnerable to Destroyers, but extremely strong against Battleships and Carriers which basically cannot hurt them.

-Carriers are the odd ones out that don't really fall into the Rocks Paper Scissors circle. They can send scout planes all over the map, making them excellent for recon, and can harass ships with dive bombers, destroy enemy planes with fighters, and even take out subs with torpedo bombers. However, planes can be shot down fairly easy if the victim is paying attention, so they are most effective at taking out ships already engaged in combat.

What ends up happening in most matches is, the Battleships and Carriers sit back, while the Destroyers, Subs, and Cruisers usually charge in. Carriers are ironically the first to the front lines with their planes. Because Battleships are the most powerful in terms of dealing damage, the trick is to scout out the position of the enemy Battleships so that your Battleships can destroy the enemy's while yours stay hidden. Alternatively, if your Submarines can sneak past the enemy Destroyers, they can easily destroy their Battleships and Carriers as well.

Or if you like to yolo it up like me, you can just play a Destroyer and charge straight at the enemy Battleship. If you're still in one piece by the time you get close, you're going to be getting a lot of kills.

This variety makes every ship play totally differently, you really feel like you are important to your team as everyone has their own role to play. It's free and worth your time.

reviewText:
Where to start!

This game has real potential, from fleet battles to the 5v5 competitive tourneyments, to the simple attention to detail the devs have put into the various weapon systems and aircraft in game is truely impressive.  Are there issues with the game? yep, but, what game doesnt have its kinks.   This game has alot of potential and in my opinion far surpasses Wargamings attempt at Naval Combat.

If you are looking for a true naval simulator, this is not your game.  This game can best be described by a mix between Navy Field and Battlestations:  Pacific.  The game is easy to learn, but hard to master with a unique crew system and interesting scouting dynamics.

What this game desperatly needs is players! and guys its free so why not give it a shot!

Pros:   Fleet system
Competitive battle system
Excellent matchmaking
Subs!
No silly aim assist
Workable AAA mounts

Cons:  Graphics
Performance
Low Community Count

TLDR:  Try it out, its free and an enjoyable mix of realism and fantasy!

reviewText:
TL;DR if you feel WoWs lacks atmosphere and a bit of grit, then SO is better. Overall SOs mechanics fit the arcade genre better, while WoWs should go more towards realism with its mechanics. Btw. this game has longer development than WoWs. So don't be a that its-a-copy guy.

Better than WoWs? a +/- list (+ is better in SO) - IMHO oc
+ All ship roles usefull
+ Gunrange to map size fits better, less campy (less hanging back), more engaged battles. Quick clever manovers make sense in SO and are less risky then in WoWs.
+ gameplay feels more dynamic
+ aiming takes longer, hitting seems harder -> enables fast ships to actually use their speed
+ Submarines (not OP, apparently it could be done)
+ grittier interface
+ slightly better sounds/ weapons boom
+ more fair commander/crew system (no gold resets)
+ for some reason MM does not seem to matter so much for the fun you have
[+ a lot less crying by the community]
- graphics can be slow on high ship details (perhaps CPU bound)
- gold ammo (though it seems a lot less OP than in WoT)
- WoWs look a tad better
- both games seem fairly slow research wise. But in SO the grind seems more fun.
+- the damage decals are more accurate in SO but look better in WoWs

+++ in SO the ingame name Das Boot" was still available >:D"

reviewText:
So far this seems like a decently fun game. I've only played it a few minutes, and the only reason I stopped (for the moment) is due to a crash that occurred. Since this is still a very new game, I can certainly understand that such is to be expected. Rather than complain, I'll explain what I was doing when the error and subsequent crash happened, in hopes that the developer(s) will be able to look into it.

I was just getting into the Radio and Recon tutorial (the second tutorial). I was firing my weapons at the first enemy target. I'd already fired one salvo of my main guns, and landed hits. Then I fired a salvo of torpedoes, immediately backed by switching to and firing a salvo of my main guns again. This is when the game crashed and closed, showing a small error dialogue with Chinese Hanzi (I sadly do not know how to read any Chinese Hanzi, so do not know what it said) and the word ERROR immediately next to the Chinese Hanzi.

Just in case it helps to give the devs some insight to the error, here are my system specifications:
Motherboard: Gigabyte Technology Co., Ltd. GA-MA770T-UD3P
CPU: AMD Phenom II X3 720 2.8 GHz
GPU: AMD Radeon HD6670 2 GB with latest driver
DirectX Version: DirectX 11 (I usually run my games on DirectX 9, though, as I find it's usually more stable)
RAM: 8 GB DDR3
Internet Connection: FibreOp, 200 Down, 50 Up

Being someone who is used to seeing errors, bugs, and crashes happen in early stages of development of either new games, or new game content, I know that these happen all the time in said situations. Fun game so far, and I'll try more later. In the meantime, hoping the developers will be able to gain some insight into the error (and hope my information provided will help them do so).

Looking forward to playing more. :)

reviewText:
Seems to be some kind of Chinese World of Warships clone...that being said, it isn't exactly half bad.

The game is a LOT like world of warships, with some very minor differences. The gameplay in this is a bit tighter and faster paced, and some would probably even like it over Warships. The ships even have a bit more to them and it puts you into the real game a little faster.

That being said, almost everything else is like warships, except with a little less backbone to it, and slightly worse visuals, and cartoony characters that randomly pop up in menus.

Not many people play this, and the producers and developers are both some unknown asian companies, and I just doubt they can compete for any type of longevity versus a game more fleshed out, with a larger budget, and more players having already devled deep into it.

An okay game with some nice aspects, but unfortuantely World Of Warships will honestly just sink this one.

reviewText:
Even trough only playing at tier 1 for some 1.5 hours, the pros and cons of this came are obvious and i feel confident to review this game.

Steel Ocean is promising, yet it still needs alot of work; don't let the fact that it looks like a chinese clone of World of Warships stop you from playing the game, it is good.
Still, its plagued by the fact that its community is rather small, (looks like you get in average of 1 minute wating to get a match); over-complicated menus; un-optimized graphics and the game at is whole, and laggy servers.

BUT it adds interesting features, like the ''artillery view'' reticle while aming, and the fact that has submarines - (something that World of Warships isn't adding) has few prototype ships (I am looking at you, Wargaming) and at a whole, the game looks promising and very entertaining. Still, i will not put a thumbs up in this review, (for now), but when the game updates and gets better in quality, i think it will be a game that will compete with World of Warships.

For now, i will give an 6.5/10.

reviewText:
Saw some reviews saying it's got great graphic in ultra setting, felt bad about my original review, re-installed the game, set everything to ultra, still look like ♥♥♥♥ (i have an ipad game with ship models that look better than this), deleted the game from library again.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
original reveiw:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To be honest, the weapon controls are super fun, but the ship movement models, they're just horrible. It's like dragging a paper box on your desk, the ship speeds up like a race car, breaks like an UFO, it's just no where near what a warship should be like. Hard to describe what exactly went wrong, it just doesn't feel right.

Judging by the interface, I'd say it's a copycat of Battle Station: Pacific. It just reminds me so much of that game, everything seems to be exactly the same. The whole thing just feels like they brought BS:P back to life and mix-breed with WoT which is actually the fun part of the game.

What pisses me off the most is, if they're copying an old classic, they shoul atleast make it look better, with a more decent graphic and interface, after all, that game they're copying is published 6 years ago. But no, just like everyone else said, it's graphics is terrible.

People have made games with better graphics in the 00's.

I've had some frustrating times playing World of Warships, but after playing this, I think I'll enjoy WoW just fine.

reviewText:
When I saw Steel Ocean, I was more enticed by the Repulse package than I was the game. World of Warships is fantastic, and I've no need for an alternative, however Steel Ocean appeared to be offering me what seemed to be a good buy (free ship!) so I decided to do it. Boy, was I disappointed.

The game itself tries, and fails, to be a World of Warships clone. It includes EVERYTHING - and I mean EVERYTHING - about World of Warships into it, EXCEPT the graphics, excellent model designs, and excellent physics. It is, by far, a try hard and not a game I am very interested in.

So, excuse me while I go play World of Warships.

reviewText:
I enjoyed it a bit, but the graphics are fair, I didn't care for the UI much, nor the damage font/color.

On a side note: I don't understand why warship games such as this game & World of Warships puts rust all over their ships. My grandfather served on USS Iowa during Korea, his ship and other ships were kept in pristine condition during service. That isn't an exaggeration. These ships were the homes for Sailors and Marines for months and years. When I see the ships in these games, it's like they pulled them out of decommission graveyards such as the one my grandpa visited in San Pedro, LA to see a rotten version of his ship.

If a ship is put back into service, they're cleaned up, restored, and upgraded with modern tech ( sometimes weapons) like USS Iowa was over the years before being transported by tug boats to it's current resting place. I've read that they were going to sink it in the past, but haven't read updates on it.

reviewText:
More FPS than Simulation.

The ships drive like go-carts.  Part of the intensity of naval combat is waiting for your guns to come to bear.  Ships that steer quickly negate the delay in placing the guns on target.

The aiming system treats the gun accuracy as if this is an FPS.  Holding aim longer improves the accuracy.  This introduces a level of intensity in taking a shot.  However, this method does not hold up well as a simulation.

The ship spotting system is a novel approach.  Ship positioning becomes a tactic in determining enemy disposition.

I must admit.  I only played for just over half an hour.  However, the first mission felt like a shooter game with waves of enemy coming at me.

Overall, I prefer a simulation which is less FPS and more about planning and tactics.
